148496986.review: I bought this game during a sale somewhere in summer 2023, and oh my freaking god! The game starts out simple. You platform across a series of extremely well designed levels using some of the best controls I've ever seen, with very high difficulty that never becomes unfair. But after 3 hours or so into the game, it turns into a metroidvania with world changing mechanics similar to Guacamelee that have you switch from the 8-bit to 16-bit era. But it still keeps the same tight level design from before and turns it into an open world game, without it feeling out of place! The game also has an extremely goofy, self aware tongue-in-cheek sense of humor that makes a ton of jokes about video game clichés, but that doesn't stop the game from having a semi-serious story that's just as awesome as the gameplay. Did I mention that the soundtrack is absolutely amazing, in both the 8-bit and 16-bit eras? Honestly, my only criticisms are that it often tends to continue on when it looks like it's about to end and that its fast travel points are really far apart, causing you to have to backtrack a lot. But overall, I really highly recommend this game to people who enjoy challenging platforming and metroidvanias.

147055878.review:
tl;dr: The messenger is a tight platformer with a terrible second half that is speaks to the nostalgic crowd that remember holding that NES controller. 

It is obvious that this is a labour of love. The aesthetics, music and gameplay really cash in on the nostalgia of people who were just awed by this 30 years ago. The controls are super tight and the difficulty hard but not unfair. 

The first few hours - when the game is still completely linear - were a lot of fun for me. You expand your move set, start understanding mechanics better and improve at the game. Quite quickly you go zooming through the levels, which feels nice. The writing is fun. The first few bosses are hard enough that winning first try is probably not the default but easy enough that after a few tries you can get them. Once you beat the demon general the game becomes too trivial, a metroidvania and completely falls off a cliff. 

You get the ability to revisit and explore all areas. That feels incredibly unrewarding though, the quests are super obscure, traversal takes forever and is nothing but a chore. I assume most people either use a walkthrough here or stop playing. For the rest of the game, all remaining bosses are gimmicky and trivial - including the final boss. My guess would be that the devs started crafting the first few levels and simply ran out of time. They included the metroidvania part to artificially increase the playtime. 

After 12 hours I have seen every area and beaten every boss of the base game and I wasn't even rushing it. I have tried the DLC for 15 minutes but it starts with a long gimmicky QTE sequence, so I stopped it again.

In the end, I'd recommend this game for people who a) enjoy tight platformers and b) appreciate the 8 bit nostalgia. Everyone else should stay away from this one though.

The Messenger is a semi-linear 2d platformer game with similarities to Ninja Gaiden. The graphics are fine and the music is excellent. The game is not a perfect masterpiece however -- everything else is good, but flawed.

The controls are good, but the most common inputs are jump->attack and attack->jump with no time between either. This is very annoying, and makes me wonder if other buttons could've been used for these. The controls aren't *bad*, they just feel under-tested.

The story is annoying. It manages to mostly make sense, but it's not... interesting. The characters are all jokes, and the dialog is only semi-skippable.

The attempt at pseudo-metroidvania doesn't work. It makes the game "non-linear" but in an uninteresting way. It's more "use keys to open doors" with the keys scattered around forcing replay of earlier areas in a specific and non-obvious order.

The difficulty is, I think, the game's biggest problem. The hardest parts are satisfyingly challenging, and the easiest parts are lovely tutorials, but they're not properly sorted. This uneven difficulty can lead to players less used to the genre giving up, or players more comfortable with the genre wondering why the game went back to being too easy and boring.

Overall, these flaws don't prevent the game from being an easy recommend. It's great fun and worth the price of admission, especially if you enjoy the genre. The journey is worth taking, just be ready to run into the game's rough edges on the way.

146232304.review:
Most people should play this. No one should feel compelled to finish it.

“The Messenger” oozes homage and charm in equal measure from the first moment of play. Its sleeve proudly bears many corsages (and other declarations of love) for Ninja Gaiden, Metroid, even a bit of Mega Man. It fires on so many cylinders: the aesthetic is amazing; the level design impeccable; the bosses are exhilarating and gorgeous; the soundtrack is wonderful. Even the writing is great, with its on-point mix of self-deprecating sarcasm and fourth wall breaks that keeps things moving both smoothly and humorously. In as far as I can tell, “The Messenger” deserves every bit of praise it receives in these regards. Indeed, the first half of the game is an object lesson in how to harness the power of nostalgia as a means of creating something new-ish, if not necessarily truly novel.

Sadly, I didn't see much of the second half of the game. I stopped in the Underworld; I couldn't manage the climb where you have to outrun the lava. This section, as well as the chase sequences in the previous zone, laid bare a problem I had noticed at the beginning of the game. I'm not talking about a distinct lack of aptitude for platformers. It's true that I'm not good at them, but I'm not the same kind of terrible at platformers as I am at bullet hells. No, this was unrelated to my ineptitude. “The Messenger” is inconsistent with it's controls in a way I haven't seen in a long, long time. Maybe ever, as far as my experience with the platformer genre is concerned. It was so pronounced that I found myself wondering if I was playing the same game as other people.

The issue isn't that sometimes the game will drop or delay an input. That happens with every game and is part and parcel with the hobby. In fact, I would rate “The Messenger” as one of the most responsive games I've played in recent memory. Without fail, when I pushed a button, something would happen. The problem was that it wasn't always the thing I expected to happen. Need to make a big jump? It would happen. Usually. Sometimes, though, it would be a baby jump. Need to jump then glide? That, too, would happen... albeit far less reliably. Need to throw that not-grappling hook to grab the wall? Maybe it'll grab at ~six body lengths. Maybe you need to be within three lengths. Who's to say? The rope dart always fired, but whether or not it would work was difficult to determine since previous success or failure with it wasn't a reliable indicator for the situation at hand. Just took some damage during a glide or jump; must have been too close to that spinning gear/blade trap, even though my model never quite made contact with it. When riding a platform near an environmental hazard or trap, though? Character model passes clean through said hazard, sometimes up to the waist, like the thing wasn't even there.

I suspect that many players, perhaps most, could soldier on through and complete the game in spite of the aggravation brought about by the above mentioned inconsistencies. While I could not bring myself to do so, it would be borderline criminal to forget how utterly enjoyable the game is until you reach your limit with the 'will they/won't they' controls. When all is said and done, it's the sense of magic and pleasure instilled by the first part of the game that makes it an easy recommendation. Go into it knowing that you could reach a point where you want to cloud-step on your controller. Armed with this knowledge, you will be better prepared for your own time with “The Messenger” to include a more favorable ratio of delight to despair.

The Messenger is proabably one of the best platformers I have ever had the pleasure of playing. The 8-bit and 16-bit artstyles are absolutely gorgeous, especially the sprites are exceptionally well done. Controls are tight and responsive (as should be expected from a platformer), and the movement mechanics the game gradually introduces all feel well explained and fit together nicely to create great platforming experiences. About halfway in, the game also introduces a switch mechanic that switches the whole artstyle, music and the soundeffects from 8- to 16-bit versions and is one of the coolest mechanics I've seen in a game bar none. Said switch mechanic also impacts gameplay in a big way I do not want to spoil, and it's cool to see little flourishes change between both versions of the game (all of the sprites being more fluidly animated in the 16-bit version, for example).
 Not far after the introduction of this mechanic, the game in a very bold move trades the whole concept of a linear platformer to that of a more open Metroidvania, including backtracking and finding hidden areas. For that, the game sadly trades some of the conciseness and good pacing it had beforehand which is a bit of a bummer, but the platforming and movement mechanics still make for an absolutely fun experience; it's just sad the second half of the game doesn't exactly stand up to the first.

To be clear, I still had an absolute blast even in the slightly weaker second half of the game. Pair all of this with absolutely outstanding music and well-timed humour and you get this gem. I myself got the game on sale for 5 bucks, but I would gladly pay full price for a game this good. An easy recommendation if you like platformers and old NES - SNES type aesthetics.

145636265.review:
A great platformer, an okay metroidvania		

So, I bought this game after sea of stars came out in order to get acquainted with the universe in which the latter is set in. By watching some gameplay footage, it looked interesting enough to captivate my sights and, indeed, it was. The game is really cool, it has a nice aesthetic to it and the 8/16-bit art is gorgeous. Overall, the enjoyment one gets is not only nostalgia driven, but as a gamer that started its career in the 8-bit systems as a little child, it does hit some pretty nostalgic nerves in a very good way.

Skipping this part and at the same time recognizing its merits, I’d like to focus here on what this game does best: intertwining different aspects of a game. Everything within the game is woven and packed around the need to give a meaning to time travel within the game. So, because this is the case, the gameplay, the story, the storytelling, the world building and the plot are all tied together in this massive idea of the need for time travel. It does get explained quite well by the end of it and the unfolding is equally delightful to experience, from the transition the game has from platforming to metroidvania to its reveals of different aspects. I respect and also feel it like a blessing that we have a game that manages to be meaningful without trying too hard and with heaps of acidic humor/self-conscious jokes here and there. This is, by and large, the game strongest aspect, the platforming being the second one (and I love some good 2d platforms, I’m an avid MMX/Metroid fan)

The combat, on the other hand, is nothing special and, as 8-bit games tended to be, quite repetitive. The same goes for the metroidvania aspect of it. It adds some hours of gameplay, but the backtracking is harder than it could be since the travel mechanic leaves you too far away to collect what you need to collect. 
The hint mechanic, which helps you if you’re stuck, is a great addition, since it removes the need to go online and look for anything. If you’re stuck you just pay 300 in game currency and it tells you where to go. This gives you both a sense of accomplishment for knowing what to do on your own and a sense of “I don’t need to look for something in every corner, get bored and keep guessing” if you don’t know where to go. You can either farm the money (which is quite easy) or look for the next place to go, it’s your choice. 

Considering how the good aspects of the game are tied with the story, the post story adventure becomes a big “?” in my head since although it might be another story to experience, it’s devoid of the game greatest asset by definition so it sounds meaningless and useless to me, although I might even finish it just because, but it also sounds like an extra not something to bash the game for.

Overall, I would recommend this to anyone who wants to play a game driven by an idea and that feels like a love letter to fans. I’m now, way more than before, looking forward to play Sea of Stars. Overall 8.5/10

145566922.review: Fun, but not flawed.  One of the best things about The Messenger is its graphics; all the environments and characters look gorgeous in both their 8-bit and 16-bit artstyles.  Another great thing is the witty, humor-filled dialogue, which is rampant throughout the first part of the game and unfortunately takes a backseat to the interesting but not as compelling lore in the second half.  The time travel mechanic is nice, if a bit surface-level.  The platforming feels tight for the most part, I enjoyed the cloudstep mechanic.  I did feel as though more upgrades were needed, as I was getting loads to begin with in the first half and then next-to-none in the second.  In general the second half is a lot weaker than the first, which is something to keep in mind.  I guess it's hard to fault the devs for this though, turning a mostly linear side-scroller into a metroidvania halfway through is ambitious and deserves to be lauded.  The Messenger also has some really tight music that blends perfectly between present and future states.  The weakest thing about this game is definitely the enemy variety.  You will see the same blue, red, and green demons a million times throughout the game, and they are not that interesting past the first level.  I really felt as though this was a missed opportunity and more interesting enemies could've been developed for the game's numerous intriguing locales.  Another thing I didn't like was the fast travel system in the second half.  I tried to break all the seals but after discovering I had missed one in an area where I'd have to play through the entire level again just to get to it, I didn't feel as though it was worth my time.  In general, the seals are a miss in my opinion.  I don't know what reward you get from collecting them all but it would've been great to have more of them along the way to actually encourage players to collect them without explicitly appealing to completionists.  One last thing this game messes up are instant-death scenarios.  Health becomes completely trivial later on in the game except for boss fights, and the only things killing you will be getting crushed or falling in a pit.  This, to me, feels like artificial difficulty, and it would've been a lot more tasteful to do crushing and pits in a similar way to Hollow Knight, where instead of instantly dying you take some damage and are teleported back to a safe spot.  Overall I liked The Messenger and I think it's an awesome first game for a clearly talented studio like Sabotage.  Definitely worth a buy especially at its sale price right now ($5).

Instant classic and probably the peak of 2d platformers. I'm 5 years late to the party here and only discovered this unknown gem by accident because I liked this developer's demo for their upcoming retro RPG, Sea of Stars, enough to want to try their first game.

What you get here is an 8-bit platformer parody game that seems mostly inspired by Ninja Gaiden at first, but gradually adds mechanical and artistic homages to other classics of the genre. 

The controls are tight and there's a bunch of movement mechanics. There's your standard wall climbing, a horizontal grappling hook that lets you reach enemies, ledges, walls and rings at a short range and enables sudden speed boosts, a Wingsuit that lets you glide horizontally and slow down your descent, and an underwater dash which if used near the surface can be used to give you a speed boost into the air horizontally.

There's also shoes that let the Messenger join the club of Hófvarpnir, Orion, Jesus, Morgan Freeman, Jim Carrey and co. by walking on the surface of still water (or lava or peanut butter). The limitation is that you can't stop or change direction on the surface without sinking, so you have to always terminate the walk with a jump or grapple if you need to dodge suddenly.

The Cloudstep, this game's take on the double jump, lets you gain extra height and chain the horizontal movement mechanics together being airborne for extended periods. Here you're not limited to a fixed number of mid-air jumps. Instead, you're awarded an extra one every time you hit a lantern, an enemy or even an enemy's projectile with your horizontal or vertical sword slash, or with the strongest version of the shuriken. Combined with speed boosted gliding it makes skilled speedruns of this game into truly awe inspiring shows. 

This is now among my favorite movement systems across all games, only behind the likes of the Quake series. 

The music is as good as it gets on the NES, the dialogue is hilarious, and the level and enemy design is interesting and varied. The early bosses are a bit too simple and easy even for newbies to this genre, but later difficulty modes fix that.

Save points are very common and deaths have very little consequence, so you're free to practice the situation you're having problems solving without having to repeat a big chunk of the level. Dying only prevents you from earning currency for movement/health/damage upgrades for a short time. But the currency is abundant (it only becomes a problem in New Game +) and you'll easily unlock everything in the shop  before you beat the game, even if you're dying often.

After you've beaten 8 levels and their 6 bosses, the cutscene seems to be taking long and something big is happening, so you might think the game is done. You got your money's worth. After all, this was about as much content as each of the original Ninja Gaiden games. 

But the credits aren't rolling.

Turns out you're not done. Now the music, sounds and graphics switch to the Sega Genesis Yamaha sound chip and gorgeous 16-bit visuals. You go through 2 big levels, beat their bosses and you're in for another longer cutscene.

"Ok, now I must be done, right? That last boss was tough to figure out."

Wrong. You're at less than a quarter of the game. Now it's no longer linear level after level. It opens up into a Metroidvania. You can now revisit the 10 levels to explore parts that weren't accessible without all the abilities you've gained by now, including the one you just earned - The Messenger's other unique contribution to the genre: the ability to shift between the 8-bit and 16-bit versions of every level, and these versions aren't just reskins of the same thing. They fundamentally change parts of the layout, making for interesting 4d puzzles (I guess I should call them 3d puzzles since this game's world is 2d) that require you to shift multiple times between modes to access certain areas. They're not too hard, just an interesting twist that adds to the richness of already having 2 versions of all levels and their music tracks.

Aside from this refresh of all the old levels, you can now reach 6 new levels with 4 bosses. One of these levels has sections, including its boss, which are a flying shoot-em-up minigame! And once you've collected all the quest McGuffins everywhere, the last non-DLC level and its boss unlock.

Then once you're done with that, the free DLC and the New Game + mode unlock. The DLC is 3 bosses on 4 levels, and they still keep getting bigger and more difficult. The first level is a surfing racer minigame reminiscent of Earthworm Jim's Andy Asteroids, or the Turbo Tunnel in Battltoads.

The last level here, the Voodoo Heart, is a series of speedrun races against a ghost image on a variety of obstacle courses. There's 25 sections and each loss gives you an easier obstacle course as your next section, and each win gives you a more difficult one. The first to reach 5 wins, uh... wins. This is my favorite level and I've spent by far the most time practicing it so far. Getting to the point where I can win all of the most difficult courses has really cleaned up my movement for the post-game challenge modes. Oh, and the boss after this level isn't your standard fight. It's a boxing minigame!

The New Game +1 option is an increase in difficulty. Basically a repeat of the whole game, but this time you take extra +1 damage from everything, bosses have more health, and deaths now incur an upfront cost in currency. You die permanently if you can't pay up. NG+1 lets you keep all your old upgrades, only losing your story/quest items that grant or ease up the access to certain areas. You get to pick just one of them to keep. Beat NG+1, and you get to pick another item and play NG+2 which is even harder.

In theory, if you live up to NG+14 or above (which means everything one shots you long before this point) and pick a new quest item each time, you start with all of them. This means the 0.01% of the players who can beat the game multiples times without ever taking damage are rewarded by basically skipping chunks of the game for a faster speedrun.

I find it lame that you can theoretically cheese your way up there as well. A less skilled player can spend absurd amounts of time farming currency to pay for their deaths, and still reach high NG+ values, which were supposed to be signs of mastery of the game, not  hundreds of hours of farming. It's a perverse incentive, but that's remedied with the free DLC. Finding all the secrets on the DLC levels unlocks a roguelike mode in New Game +1 (or higher) called THE DEAL. This doubles your health and triples your damage, but you can no longer revive at all, so the currency becomes useless and a single death ends your run.

I won't get into spoilers here, but I really like how the story of the game is meaningful despite this being a parody game. The big plot twist and a few of the reveals gave me shivers. There's hidden Easter egg visuals in the levels that prove many of the mythical stories you'll hear and discuss with the few NPCs are literally true. There's runes scattered in the backgrounds in some places. If you learn how they correspond to the Latin alphabet, you can get extra hints about the world's history. The lore stuff especially got me excited because I found this game by getting interested in the RPG that will be this game's prequel.

Overall, this is the complete package. If you're a newbie to platformers, this game's gradual ramping of difficulty and good teaching methods will accommodate you. If you're a master of the genre and Shinesparking around Metroid games is second nature to you, you'll love the high skill ceiling here. Voodoo Heart runs and particularly speed boost Wingsuit gliding will entice you while New Game + and THE DEAL will give you endless replayability. If you just want to chill with minigames or a silly epic story with interesting lore, you're covered too. Do not miss this classic.

The beginning is a little bit on the easy side, which made it feel a bit boring to me. I was motivated to keep going thanks to the amazing soundtrack, fun boss fights, and funny writing. I am SO GLAD I stuck with it because the second half of this game has a twist that elevates it to something truly special. 

The Messenger is a lot of things, but it is a platformer first. I think it does this well thanks to some really fun and satisfying movement. From the very beginning, you are granted a "cloudstep" which grants you an extra jump when you slash an enemy, object, or projectile in midair. You can chain these together, keeping you in the air for a long time if you're skilled enough. Later, you can even combine this with glides, grapples, wall jumps, and more. The levels are designed to be challenging, while still allowing players to be creative/expressive in how they approach them.

GAMEPLAY (non-story) SPOILERS AHEAD:

Halfway through the game, The Messenger becomes a Metroidvania, allowing you to go anywhere in the map. It's not perfect at this-- you must pay the shopkeeper to tell you where to go, or rely on some very vague hints instead. I resorted to a guide for this, as the rest of the shop upgrades are pretty expensive. This was pretty much the only thing about the Metroidvania portion I did not like. That aside, this half of the game is AMAZING. It introduces portals that allow you to travel between the future and the past. There are 16-bit graphics and music whenever you're in the "future", meaning the devs had to make every single level twice! It's not just a gimmick either-- this mechanic also has story implications, and quasi-puzzles designed around it. There are also much more challenging and fun areas introduced in this half.

When all of these pieces are working together, this game feels like a masterpiece. This is not the case throughout the whole game, but very close to it. It has gone on sale for as low as FIVE DOLLARS, but it is super worth it even at full price. 

8.5/10

142658285.review:
Great game!  Fans of action platformers will love it, doubly those who enjoy the retro style.  Do yourself a favor and spoil nothing about this game for yourself before giving it a try.

Few games create and preserve flow as well as this one.  Platforming and combat are blended together seamlessly:  Enemies aren't provided as a simple hindrance to level traversal, instead offering players more options of how to proceed through it.  New mechanics are introduced alongside new challenges, giving players just enough time to get used to their abilities before putting them to the test.  Challenges are tough but fair, leaving players neither bored nor frustrated.  Most areas give players surprisingly high choice on how to proceed through them, rewarding daring players with faster play without punishing players who haven't built up excessive skill.

The choice on how to attack a challenge extends to boss battles delightfully.  The one time I found myself seriously frustrated with the gameplay was during a boss battle when I was being forced to sit through the same series of attacks before I could even try to do damage.  This was especially frustrating as I had to repeat the battle many times, and had to slog through an easy early section just to get another crack at the hard part later on.  As I was lamenting this issue, I realized that I was making assumptions about the way the battle must be fought.  I changed my strategy to a more challenging and aggressive one, and immediately was back in the flow of the game.  Worse games wouldn't allow lateral thinking of this type, but this one shines.

The humor and the story are excellent, and the game never takes itself too seriously.  There's a surprising amount of heart that shows a love of the games this one takes inspiration from.  Even better, much of the story is given in short, optional bits that don't interrupt players who are having fun with the action.  They instead allow players a short respite and a peek into the world's lore in between bouts of action, which is a welcome juxtaposition.

Another benefit to the way the game delivers its story content:  Players can skip past it if they choose to replay the game using the New Game + system.  NG+ lets a player keep the abilities they earned over the course of their playthrough, and does an excellent job of preserving flow.  It allows players a second chance to play through the game and maybe experience things they didn't the first time without having to suffer the extreme frustration of having their muscle memory stripped.  Many NG+ systems allow a player to replay the game extremely over-leveled, trivializing gameplay and removing any fun.  This game's system neither punishes the player nor holds their hand.

Any of the other great things that could be said about this game would spoil it for players, which I have avoided since I'm wholeheartedly recommending it to all.  This is a great 25 hours spent, and I'm eagerly looking forward to any more projects Sabotage Studio feels they want to give.

The clean but intentional platforming puzzles between 8 and 16-bit is a cool idea and the seamless transition between adjoining soundtracks keep you in the mindset. [b] Setting & Writing: [/b]
The premise of The Messenger is one of prophecy that tells a "Western Hero" who will save them from the Demon King. Once the hero finds the ninja (you). You are tasked with taking the scroll the hero was carrying up to the mountain. What was funny to me was the Western hero telling you to travel east on your platforming journey. Just go east…in a platformer (idk I found it funny). The game contains a comfortable amount of self-awareness making it pretty funny but not 4th wall breaking. Certain power-ups given to you by NPCs are given to you because “You’re supposed to have it at this point”. However, once you arrive at the top of the mountain you’re story isn’t over. You are then sent in a time loop where you (the ninja) becomes the new western hero designated to deliver the scroll to the new hero (You went so far east that you came from the west for this new guy). Once the scroll is delivered, tradition dictates that you now become the NPC that looks over the new hero. Your first day on the job doesn’t go well when you forget to introduce him with the ability to respawn. This is where the game truly begins. From here you go on an adventure to break this time loop and put the world on the straight and narrow

[b] Gameplay system & Bosses: [/b]
The Messenger starts as a basic platformer having you move left for about the whole journey. Each set piece is typically capped off by a boss fight which has you learn the boss’s patterns. After you learn these patterns, you tend to find your opening. But after the first act of the game, the game opens in almost metroidvania like fashion. On top of the platforming tricks you were taught in the opening of the game, you’ll be tasked with using collected upgrades to go through and complete the task of the second act. These upgrades will help you traverse time-based platforming puzzles that require tight timing and precise platforming. 

[b] Quest, Mini-games & Challenges: [/b] 
The Messenger does a good job of feigning its true objective. It starts out simple, go east. After a while though your quest becomes more open ended and requires you to revisit some locations you’ve been to before and (with the help of your NPCs) some places you haven’t. There aren’t really any minigames per se in the game but there are hidden puzzle rooms (so challenges?) that truly tests your platforming skills. Completion of these rooms rewards you with a currency once collected gives you an upgrade for the protagonist.   

[b] Miscellaneous (art, music, etc.): [/b]
The developers stayed true to a vision here. The played with time travel swapping back and forth between 8-bit and 16-bit visuals here. This is such a neat way to describe changes in time. This is also reflected in the sound design which is reminiscent of going back and forth between a NES and SNES.

This game, this beautiful majestic piece of indie developing. Let me make this loud and clear, The Messenger, is not just one of the best indie games of all time, it's one of the best video games ever made. The Messenger is a action-platformer metriodvania, The best way I can explain it, is think of Ninja Gaiden meets Castlevania. The player takes on the roll of a ninja messenger who needs to take a special scroll to the top of a mountain to fulfill a prophecy to help save the world. Of course, there is much more to it than than, but I would rather not spoil it. Just believe me when I say this story is excellent. The writing is one of the best parts, not only it is charming and endearing, but also hilarious. The writers completely understand what players want from a game from the 21st century, it tells a great story, but also does not take it self too seriously. Characters have heart felt moments one minutes, and are yelling at each other the next. The banter between the messenger and the shopkeeper was top notch. Some of the funniest interactions between two characters I've ever seen in a game, they insult each other, they use massive amounts of sarcasm, all whiling continuing the story. Phenomenal stuff. The game play itself is absolute bliss. As I mentioned early, it really is ninja gaiden meets castlevaina. The messenger can run, jump, attack with his katana and use shurikens, All of it is concise, fluid, and fast passed action. Another game that does not cheat you at all, but I will say you better be quite skilled in this genre because this game does not **** around. The messenger starts hard and doesn't stop until it reaches masochistic levels of difficulty. If you have what it takes to get through it, I PROMISE it's 100% worth it. This game gives me the same feeling any soulslike does, even when a level that should take only 15 minutes to get through turns into a hr when you do get through it, it's gaming euphoria. The enemies, minimal platforms, constant movement does expect near perfection, but it's attention to detail, makes every level so much fun, despite it's high difficulty.

*Spoliers Ahead*
One thing I do need to mention is the games massive change. For the 1st half of the game, The Messenger is really a linear 8-bit style Ninja Gaiden clone, and then IT happens. Without going too much into story details, the game *sends* the player into the future.....a 16-bit style NG / Castlevania-esque future, and then it hits you. 8-bit is the past, 16-bit is the future and it starts to combine the two styles in one of the best ways I have ever seen. Of course with the the linear level after level game play, it turns into an interconnected mteriodvanina style map, where the player needs to re-explore every level in any order they wish, with multiple news one also unlock-able. The entire change in design, sound, and game play was one of the coolest twists ever in a video game in my opinion, and going back and forth watching each level change from 8-bit to 16-bit and back was a dream. (The music also changes with it)

The Messenger, by Sabotage Games, was/ still is one of the best games I have played in a long time. Honestly, if I made a list of top 25 games, you can be sure this makes it. Everything from the game play, story, exploration, unlockables, all of it is just top notch. I can't wait for their next game Sea of Stars releasing in August, Sabotage Games is a new favorite developer of mine.

Oh! Did I mention the game has a free DLC that adds another 5-7hrs of game play? Because there's that too!

9.7/10

When I first saw the Messenger, I decided to pass on it since it had "old school" graphics, and I typically don't like "old school" games. However, I was kind of running out of games to play, so I decided to give various games a try, including this one. I am happy to say that I was pleasantly surprised by The Messenger.

There are two main reasons why I typically don't like "old school" games:
	• Your character typically can't do much: The difficulty from old school games typically comes from how limited your character is, not that the challenge itself is all that cool or interesting to overcome. E.g. in the original Megaman, your character could only run, slide, jump, and attack horizontally. Because of your character's limited moveset, enemies/attacks that normally wouldn't be all that challenging suddenly become so. E.g. an enemy who stays in the air a lot is a huge challenge since you can't reach them. I personally don't find this very engaging.
	• The overall pace of the game is very slow paced: Typically, in old school games it's pretty easy to die (e.g. falling into a pit or spikes means instant death. Checkpoints are far away and it's hard to heal so enemies dealing damage matters a lot). Therefore, you typically always have to play very methodically in order to progress. While I am fine with playing methodically for boss battles and certain encounters, I don't want to do so THROUGHOUT the entire playthrough. 

Thankfully, Messenger doesn't suffer from these problems. I never felt gimped in any scenario, thinking that if my character could just do one thing then the game would be so much easier. The overall pace of the game is also decently fast paced, only requiring you to slow down for puzzle/platforming challenges. 

A big reason for this is that the biggest challenge in Messenger is not from the enemies, it's from the platforming. Enemies only take like a quarter of your health and can die in like 1-3 hits. So you can very often just run up straight to an enemy, attack them, and then kill them. So the enemies don't really slow the game down. It also helps a lot that you can move while attacking.

The platforming however is far more dangerous with multiple instant death scenarios (e.g. falling into a pit means instant death). I normally don't like this since I much prefer combat challenges than platforming challenges (which is why a game like Super Meatboy is a 6/10 for me). The bosses are also basically a series of platforming challenges. You typically dodge a number of attacks until the boss opens themselves to a very clear opening, and then you attack them. It's not really a constant mix of defense and offense, and more so geared towards defense (i.e. dodging through platforming). 

While the fact that the main challenge from this game comes from the platforming definitely reduces the score of this game (i.e. main reason why it's a 7/10 and not a 8 or 9), I still enjoyed this game. It's fun to simply move in this game and go to places. It's fun to kill enemies quickly. It's fun to use the grappling shot and close long distances quickly. It's hard to pinpoint exactly why, but just controlling your character in this game and doing shit is an enjoyable experience. I think this goes to show that while I don't like "precision" platforming all that much, I do enjoy "spectacle" platforming.

139703777.review:
[h1]DELIVERING A MESSAGE OF GREATNESS[/h1]

The Messenger is, above all else, comforting. Whether you’re traversing a room riddled with traps, listening to the Shopkeeper spin a new yarn, or charging forward to give that one boss another go, every individual element combines to create an experience that feels genuinely refreshing. At times funny, at other times thrilling, The Messenger captivated me from beginning to end through its charm and challenging platforming.

Directly inspired by Ninja Gaiden, The Messenger is not just another retro 2D action-platformer despite what its appearance would suggest. While a familiarity with the Nintendo games of yore that serve as an influence will undoubtedly make the small improvements and shout outs all the more noticeable, nostalgia is not the overriding factor here. Instead, The Messenger uses your expectations of the genre to great effect, crafting a journey that continually surprised me even after ten hours of gameplay.

It starts with a simple intro that belies the true nature of The Messenger. Humanity has been crushed by a demon army, with only a small pocket of survivors still alive on a remote island who have been practicing for years awaiting the next invasion and the coming of a prophesied figure called the Western Hero. It is as cliché and rote as it sounds.

But whereas other games would have you play as the fabled Western Hero, you are but a Messenger tasked with delivering a scroll to the highest peak in the realm. In short, you’re a delivery boy, but one who is capable of defeating scores of demons and inciting fear into their hearts. From the get go, The Messenger is tongue in cheek, playing with genre expectations to craft a story that continually surprises with its irreverent tone.

Much of the charm comes through via the dialogue, most of which is a direct result of the NPC that you will interact with the most. The Shopkeeper is exactly what his name implies; he runs and operates the shop through which you upgrade your abilities and earn new items over the course of your journey. Yet more than that, he is the Messenger’s constant companion, offering sardonic commentary on your progress while telling tales that serve no purpose. And as much as he all-too frequently offers meta commentary on the game as a whole, his changing relationship with the Messenger serves as a steady cornerstone on which The Messenger can build.

It’s telling that the most dramatic and unnerving moments in The Messenger revolve around the Shopkeeper. His reactions, or the lack thereof, ratchet up the tension where there was none beforehand. The Shopkeeper is your best friend, your cheerleader, the person who will mock you relentlessly for every mistake, and is written to near-perfection.

That’s not to say the rest of the cast is anything to scoff at. I came to love the thick headedness of the Messenger as he failed to grasp the meaning behind the words of others…like the ogres who love to work out, the wannabe necromancer and his evil talking staff, and the spirit who just wants to dig a hole. As brief as their scenes are, they leave a big impact, and create much of the joy along the way. Some jokes take hours to pull off, but when they hit, I couldn’t help but chuckle at how well planned it all was.
 
Outside of the upgrades that you earn over the course of the game, the primary movement mechanic of The Messenger is called cloudstepping. Whenever you hit a projectile, enemy, or target with your sword, you can immediately jump again, allowing you to chain together jumps to get over obstacles and reach places you normally wouldn’t have access to. This is a difficult move to pull off in the beginning, but it didn’t take long for me to grasp its implications and chain together attacks so that I could stay continually airborne. It’s a very cool mechanic that provides some measure of control over the normal double jump, and is a pivotal move in your arsenal through each of The Messenger’s levels.

Proper pacing is oftentimes difficult to achieve, but here, it feels natural. The rate at which you gain new skills never felt rushed to me, with each new area providing plenty of opportunities to practice and work on your moves. My successes and failures were mine alone, and I never felt like it was a cheap mechanic or a poorly structured obstacle that did me in. This is a good thing, as the failures come repeatedly and without mercy, particularly during a boss fight. You do have a health bar, which provides some leeway when facing enemies but does little when you have to content with spike lined pits and other traps that will often cause instant death.

At least dying is a minor inconvenience due to the lack of lives. Rather than restart a level upon death, you respawn back at the nearest checkpoint with a small demon named Quarble tailing you. He’ll follow you around until he either gets bored and leaves, or until he eats a requisite number of Time Shards, which is the currency used to purchase upgrades. It’s a straightforward system that is not too penalizing while still providing some consequence for failure. It may not seem like much, but those Time Shards will be missed when you’re itching the purchase the more expensive upgrades.

A personal highlight in my time with The Messenger was the boss fights, which are as numerous as they are challenging. Their ever increasing difficulty is indicative of how strong the pacing is as a whole. Earlier bosses focus on simple movement mechanics or task you with using your new abilities to their full potential. I particularly enjoyed the end game battles, which are unforgiving yet so satisfying to overcome when I realized just how flexible the limited abilities at your disposal are.

Though the main story is well-paced and balanced in terms of difficulty, that goes out of the way if you search for the optional Power Seals. These are collectibles that open a chest in the shop and are not required to complete the story. Which is good, as the hidden locations you find them in are by far the most punishing areas in the world. They require pinpoint accuracy and quick thinking to traverse, and are worth tackling later in the game once you’ve grown accustomed to the controls and have developed nerves of steel. I tried my hand at a few of these, and while I struggled with most of them, they do provide some of the best platforming challenges available.

It’s also helped by the design of the levels themselves. They’re challenging yet fair from a gameplay perspective, but are absolutely gorgeous in terms of design and animation. Each level has a certain appeal to it, from muddy and thorny swamps to glacial peaks, which is further enhanced when you change between eras. The Messenger doesn’t stick to the colour palette found in the NES and SNES era which allows for a greater variety and depth to the foliage and enemies you encounter.
 
The little details are what make The Messenger shine. When you dive underwater, the music is muffled to reflect the change in acoustics. A sword slash sounds noticeably different in the 16-bit era compared to its 8-bit counterpart. The way the eye of an enemy glints just a half second before launching across the battlefield. How a single level manages to be intimately familiar despite the changing times. There are so many small elements like this that don’t do much by themselves, but added together, offer so much to the experience.

All this is to say that The Messenger is phenomenal. Its platforming and exploration are some of the best I’ve played in years, the tight controls meshing well with a small but immensely enjoyable toolkit. It exudes character throughout, using delightful and witty dialogue to fill the world with charm against the backdrop of a beautiful world filled with secrets. With The Messenger, Sabotage blends all this together into a harmonious package that pays tribute to its forebears while standing proudly on its own.

The Messenger starts as a simple retro platformer with simple mechanics. The only "gimmick" at first is that if you hit something with your sword while in the air, you gain a second jump, and you can do this ad nauseum. This allows for a fun level traversal mechanic where you can use a combination of a jumping/spamming attack to "float" through levels, and allows for some interesting platforming sections, as well as a ton of fun ways to "skip" content for speedrunning.

However, this section of the game starts to wear thin by the end...until you realize the game hasn't ended. I don't want to spoil too much here, but there is a very very different "second half" of the game that completely changes everything. And no, it's not going from NES graphics to SNES graphics.

Up until that point, the game is maybe above average, with some great boss fights, but others very much not so great, and overly long levels that start repeating mechanics too readily.

After that point, the game becomes a completely different, much better game. My only regret is that it takes ~4-5 hours minimum to get to the point where the game really snaps into place. Additionally, I feel like interesting power-ups are doled out too slowly for much of the early game.

To be clear, I think those first 4-5 hours are necessary for the "reveal" to hit as hard as it does, and be as awesome as it is. I just don't know if some people will be turned off by the more simpler early part of the game.

Overall, the second half of the game is phenomenal, and the first half is by no means bad, it's just a little too long in my opinion, for whatever that is worth. But it is *absolutely* worth pushing through.

137544980.review:
The Messenger is a great action platformer inspired by NES Ninja Gaiden, with a lot of cool twists. However, to properly talk about the game, you need to discuss some of those twists.
Attack options are basic. You have a sword with short reach and long-range shuriken that are limited. But you have a lot of options for movement. Instead of a double jump, you have a Cloudstep, which gives you an extra jump after a successful sword attack. And it works on enemies, projectiles, or environmental lanterns. The best part is that you can combo multiple Cloudsteps. As long as you have something to land an attack on, you can keep jumping. And that’s just the basic jump mechanic. Eventually, you’ll get even more options that also work together, giving you a lot of mobility options.
However, sometimes chaining these different moves isn’t easy. Instead of doing what you want, you’ll pull a different move, which is annoying and can lead to a frustrating death. The controls are precise, but the button layout isn’t the best. For example, with an Xbox controller, you jump with A and attack with X. Precise Cloudsteps require both buttons, and you only have one thumb to press both. Yes, you can change the layout, but the default one should be better. But since it’s a matter of skill, you’ll improve over time.
The game starts in 8-bit linear stages, but after a few hours, they’ll shift to 16-bit. And shortly after that, the game also changes to a metroidvania, which is a great twist. During that part of the game, you’ll shift between 8-bit and 16-bit in the same stage, but only at predetermined spots. This dual-layer mechanic isn’t new, but I love the implementation. The transitions are smooth, both in graphics and music. Speaking of music, it’s great. Some tracks are amazing, both in 8-bit and 16-bit. The pixel art is also great, in both modes.
The metroidvania elements, however, are a bit lacking. You don’t get new upgrades, there are only a few bosses, and the new items you get only open new areas. There’s a lot of backtracking with only a few fast travel locations. At least it’s easy to go back to the main hub. It’s not that bad if you think the game is a metroidvania from the beginning, just with a lot of gatekeeping to keep you on the main path. But since the game uses that as a cool twist, you don’t have that perception. Still, there are a lot of cool areas to explore, although the game lacks enemy variety.
The game is challenging but not hardcore. Collecting all optional items can be tough, but the reward is underwhelming. There’s also a free DLC that adds even more areas, and it’s a welcome addition. Most achievements are natural to get, but some are missable, and one in the DLC is particularly annoying. After beating the game, you unlock New Game+ with an increased difficulty if you want. In any case, lack of content isn’t an issue.
The story is also interesting, with fun interactions with NPCs. But those, you’ll have to find out for yourself. However, there’s a plot dump out of nowhere near the end that feels awkward.
I can see why some rate this game very highly. It has a lot of cool ideas and twists that were never done before, at least in this way. The game is fun and engaging, with great gameplay. But for me, it has some issues that prevent it from being an amazing title. But it’s still a great game that I can easily recommend on sale.

137385459.review:
The Messenger is a genre-blending Action Platformer developed by Quebec-based studio “Sabotage” and published by Devolver Digital. The 23 man indie studio, established in 2016, already made a massive splash on the indie game scene with their first release “The Messenger” (and for good reason) and everything is pointing to them gearing up for another exciting venture, with their sophomore release “Sea of Stars”. The developer's website can be found [url=https://sabotagestudio.com/team/]here[/url].
The Messenger follows a Ninja, tasked with delivering a scroll of great importance to the top of an icy peak, a perilous journey to save humanity’s last bastion of hope against the ceaseless invasions of the horrible Demon King, his village off on the far Western shore. Donning the title of the Messenger, he sets off, aided by the ever quippy supernatural aid of the mysterious, robed “Shopkeeper”.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
[h2]CONS[/h2]
- A bit too much backtracking at times, even for Metroidvania standards (though bear in mind it’s a careful and subjective balance)
- One bug (got stuck crouching in a wall, because of a moving platform)
- Little, unskippable cutscene every time a power seal is picked up (there are over 45 in the game)
- One leap of faith in the [spoiler]Forlorn Temple[/spoiler]
- [spoiler]Wall grabbing[/spoiler] seems a little buggy in game’s final area

[h2]PROS[/h2]
+ One of the best soundtracks (especially on the chiptune side of things) in video game history
+ The greatest narrative I’ve had the pleasure of experiencing in an Action Platformer, bar none
+ Some of the most wonderful writing (especially of dialogues and jokes within said dialogues) I’ve witnessed, in and outside of the video game medium
+ Awe-Inspiring use of genre-blending and environmental/visual storytelling
+ Ridiculously funny at times
+ Splendid philosophical moments

[h1]Review[/h1]
The young, Quebec studio kept busy for the first two years of their establishment, delivering “The Messenger” onto PCs on the 30th August 2018. Having done all of the game’s achievements, barring one (because of my own carelessness), the game took me 20 hours to fully complete, and about 17 or so to fully complete a first playthrough (with the free Picnic Panic DLC).

[h2]Music[/h2]
The game’s composer “Rainbowdragoneyes” has not only succeeded at making a masterful, electrifying soundtrack, but shows an impeccable musical competency through his use of leitmotifs, and his ability to make iterative musical pieces of varying complexity, that are never overburdening, as well as intelligently using certain distorting and compressing effects to seamlessly emulate the chiptune melodies of old, while still retaining a slick, modern feel.

[h2]Gameplay & Controls[/h2]
The controls and general handling of the character are about as buttery as its gets. Your character is not just a ninja for show, cosmetically, he is a ninja master of mobility par excellence. And as you acquire more and more abilities for your traversal of the in-game world (which often intelligently and handily double as combat abilities), you will feel the flow of the game increase. Though, quite amazingly, the game feels tight and fast and snappy from the very beginning, even before acquiring the more interesting abilities later down the line (though not too late, thankfully!).
The beginning of the game is your standard affair for the most part: Run, Jump, Slash. The only unique ability at the start lies in the game’s “Cloudstep”. It entails hitting lanterns, candelabras, skulls and other debris stuck to the game’s background walls (and, soon enough, enemy projectiles, too) to renew your jump mid-air, indicated by a tiny icon of a gust of wind/cloud under your feet. I will not spoil the game’s other abilities, for it is a sensational joy to discover them on your own!
About 1/3 of the way through the game, you will be faced with quite the surprise, and the game’s first genre-blend/switch. Though I will not spoil more!

[h2]Graphics[/h2]
Little remains to be said about the visuals, that is not clearly seen: A fantastic emulation of the style of the early NES games, with its main inspirations worn heavy on its chunky, 8-bit sleeve. The style morphs into something beautiful and altogether different later on, and that equally inspires awe within me, and fits with two of the game’s main strengths: defying expectations and pushing the envelope of the mundane.

[h2]Writing & Story[/h2]
As already mentioned in the summary and the game’s introductory blurb, the writing of “The Messenger” is as beautiful, as it is, at times, absurd and humorous; as basic, as it is philosophical, thought-provoking and complex. The game plays a careful balancing act, prolifically teetering on the edges (not unlike a ninja) of trope-y game and a philosophical, meta think piece. It lures the player in with a well-crafted, yet somewhat plain rug, only to pull it and make it fly as soon as the player blinks, high into the sky, enough to make the, at times, stereotypical, gamified world into a self-referential and clever joke, though never at the expense of the game’s actual, main narrative. The game is always aware of what it’s doing, but never in a self-hating manner, always simply in good-hearted, and thoughtfully analytical jest.
If I was to talk about the character of the Shopkeeper, about the many intrusions beyond the fourth wall, about the short stories, parables, philosophies, the clues of which are often visible in the game’s world, as well as one of the most clever and loving integrations of a Credits sequence I have seen in any video game ever… If I was to talk about all this and more, I could write a whole essay, and I still may fall short in describing the game’s splendiferous didactic, diegetic and thought-stimulating sides.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
The Messenger is an experience beyond the scope of Steam’s word limit, and my time limit, as are many video games made these days, and in the past. I’ve stretched this service's limits while describing some of the seemingly simplest experiences this platform has to offer. The world of gaming is a world of boundless artistic expression. Whether it be a team of hundreds or thousands or the multi-talented effort of one or a few, there’s never been quite anything like the video game medium before. I hope The Messenger is saved in the annals of time, in our collective appraisal of culture through its selective rememberance, for it is one of the most impressive experiences of all time. Displaying about every side of our humanity, that you can think of: Deep, funny, sorrowful, lonely, bitter, angry, creative, resourceful, … The Messenger and the story of its creation, are an ode to humanity.

[h3]Thank You To Sabotage For Sharing Their Beautiful Art With The World, And Thanks As Always To Devolver Digital, For Remaining One Of The Greatest Havens For The Lonesome Creative And The Basement Studio Alike![/h3]

The Messenger is another one of those retro throwback platformers with a charming pixel artstyle and chiptune soundtrack. This one is very obviously inspired by the NES Ninja Gaiden games, though as other reviews have already alluded to it actually ditches its linear structure partway through and becomes a Metroidvania.

Now, I recommend this game because it's both fun and funny. Moreso the latter, as the game has a charmingly anarchic and meta sense of humour. However, potential buyers should beware, as the game is not without flaws.

Most seriously, the game has a few difficult sections that are actually required. In fact, I'd say the hardest parts of the game were mandatory sections over instant-death pits rather than any of the boss fights or optional puzzle-platforming screens. Those difficult platforming sections become even more of a pain when the game opens up, as now you have to traverse them in both directions. The lack of a traditional high-jump or double-jump further compounds the difficulty, as muscle memory from other games will get you killed a lot before you become comfortable with the game's core platforming mechanic.

There are a few other odd control problems. The game ports over the "stick to any wall even if you don't actually want to" part of Ninja Gaiden (and it doesn't get a pass just because it lampshades that fact), and the hookshot (sorry, "Rope Dart") just feels off for a number of reasons: it's too short, has odd timing, lacks impact, and often produces unpredictable results

But despite all that the game is still very fun, and many of its sections are extremely satisfying to play once you've mastered the controls.

Un juego claramente inspirado en los clásicos Ninja Gaiden (incluso bromean con eso dentro del juego), lleno de "easter eggs", referencias a otros juegos, humor absurdo (me encanta las historias del tendero), secretos, desafíos, objetos y mejoras de habilidades que irás desbloqueando. 

El juego comienza siendo un juego de acción-aventura plataformero (al estilo Ninja Gaiden, Castlevania, etc.), y cuando crees que te lo has pasado, se convierte en una especie de metroidvania (es decir, de progresión no lineal). Un giro maravilloso que le añade una gran rejugabilidad. Además cuenta con un DLC muy bueno (y gratuito) llamado Picnic Panic, que le añade aún más horas de entretenimiento. 

Un aspecto que me encanta, es que el pasado y el futuro son representados con gráficos (y sonido) al estilo de los juegos de las consolas de tercera generación (8 bits) y de cuarta generación (16 bits) respectivamente... aunque a resoluciones superiores a las que se manejaban por entonces. Los controles del juego son muy precisos, algo que me parece vital para disfrutar este tipo de juegos. Casi siempre (por no decir siempre) que he muerto ha sido por fallo mío y no del juego. Lo único molesto que recuerdo es engancharme a la pared sin querer, lo que me hizo morir unas cuantas veces o perder algún desafío de velocidad (por cierto, esto también lo menciona el protagonista del juego en uno de sus diálogos, lo que indica que son conscientes de este aspecto xD). 

En definitiva, un juego que he disfrutado mucho, aunque entiendo que no es para todo el mundo. Si te gusta este tipo de juegos y aún no lo has jugado, no te lo puedes perder.

Are you after a Metroidvania, oozing charm and passion? ( Even sometimes literal ooze? ) 
No? Then you should be.
If you have ever recalled the feeling of playing Pokemon Gold / Silver, finishing the final boss and then having a revelation that you have only reached the half way point faced with both fear and excitement ( And potentially a small break )
The Messenger is a love-letter to Metroidvania, free exploration and puzzle platforming that dares you to keep hitting that chat prompt to burn out an inexplicable amount of dialogue and doens't disappoint.
As a single play-through experience this game hits all its marks.

That being said,
The game does suffer from Post-End Game fatigue as you will find yourself re-visiting areas you have traversed through time & time again as you attempt to find the correct route with some end game mechanics introduced.
Go in with a notepad and take note of areas you are yet to access if you want to forgo a visit to the Wiki for a specific post-game area and an overall more pleasant experience as your rewarded for your curiosity.

The additional DLC shows the passion for this world and is a game to immediately share with friends.

As someone who started with the NES as his first console back in the early 90s, The Messenger was one of the best games I've ever played. 

The game starts out as a 8-bit Ninja Gaiden (NES) inspired linear platformer filled with stages/levels that have great controls, music, level design. Once you hit the halfway point of this game, it suddenly transforms into a SNES 16-bit metroidvania style game (a mix of elements from "Super Metroid & Castlevania Symphony of the Night") that's just a joy to play.

When you get to this point - you will notice that the developers still keep the 8-bit graphics style by implementing "time travel" in their level design, using portals that take you back and forth trough both 8-bit and 16-bit style of graphics. This changes how you navigate through the many areas of this game, and is a true stroke of genius because you also hear the music alternate from their respective styles.

Another important element of the game is that is provides a very solid way to progress through it. You gain new abilities from the shop using currency you collect and items from certain areas/bosses, some that just show you new areas you can then access. I usually have issues with Metroidvania-style games because they give you a little too much freedom in exploring the entirety of the map, causing me to get bored or just flat out give up; but The Messenger plays fair by forcing players to pay up to show you where to go next via the shop keeper. It gives players an in-house choice of doing it on your own or asking for a bit of help for a price - rather than looking at a guide somewhere.

The boss fights are fantastic, with a small learning curve for their patterns but still provides a fun challenge to complete. There is a decent variety of them, unlike the standard enemies in the game - but the lack of different enemies doesn't make the game feel repetitive because it's just fun to constantly slice and dice through them in each area. The level design is just so entertaining, backtracking doesn't feel like a chore especially if you feel like collecting all of the green emblems (they remind me of the DK coins in Donkey Kong Country 2 & 3). Gathering the musical notes needed for the end game also felt a little Super Mario RPG inspired, where you needed 7 stars to reach the final area. It was just the perfect mix of nostalgia that puts this game over the top for me.

My only [ever-so-small] negative opinion about this game is the power up that allows you to attack while gliding - I didn't feel it to be as smooth as the developers most likely intended. It caused a lot of deaths and hours trying to get hard-to-reach green coins, but it may just be my lack of skill - so I can't be too hard on that opinion.

Overall, I'm really happy to have finally get around to playing The Messenger. For anyone with a love for retro platformers/Metroidvania - it's a must play. For anyone younger that is new to this art style or type of game - give it a try - it's worth it at the game's price. At this time full retail is $20 but you can wait for a Steam Sale to catch this at $10-15, and at that price it's a must buy.

Jerk Score: 9.7/10

Dar ceea ce face The Messenger cu adevărat special este tranziția sa fluidă între două dimensiuni: pixel art retro și grafică modernă în stilul 16-bit. Aceasta nu doar adaugă profunzime vizuală, dar și aduce mecanici inovatoare și puzzle-uri care se bazează pe această schimbare a dimensiunii.

Povestea jocului este prezentată cu umor și farmec și dezvoltă aspecte surprinzătoare pe parcurs. Începe ca o aventură de salvare tipică, dar devine mult mai complexă pe măsură ce dezvăluie detalii din lumea jocului și personajele sale.

Atmosfera jocului este susținută de o coloană sonoră fantastică, care se potrivește perfect cu acțiunea și evoluția povestii. Muzica adaugă o dimensiune emoțională și intensifică experiența jocului.

Un posibil dezavantaj pentru unii jucători este că dificultatea jocului poate fi destul de ridicată. Anumite secțiuni și niveluri pot necesita încercări repetate și abilități de platformă avansate. Cu toate acestea, această provocare face parte din farmecul jocului și va fi apreciată de cei care caută o experiență de joc mai intensă.

În concluzie, The Messenger este un titlu de platformă indie excepțional care reușește să ofere o experiență captivantă și inovatoare. Cu gameplay inovator, poveste fermecătoare și design de nivel inspirat, acest joc este o alegere excelentă pentru oricine iubește jocurile de platformă și caută ceva proaspăt și diferit. Indiferent dacă sunteți un veteran al jocurilor de platformă sau un nou venit în gen, The Messenger vă va încânta cu siguranță și vă va ține lipiți de ecran pentru ore în șir.

Initially, I wanted to play The Messenger since I was interested in Sea of Stars. I gathered that the former was a sort of prequel (different genre and all) and it would be worth playing it in order to get the references in the latter. I'm glad that I played it, for whatever reason, because it's one of the best platformers I've ever tried.

[h1]Game Impressions[/h1]
[b]+ Art style:[/b] Amazing, in and of itself, but the game has a very cool mechanic: time travelling through portals (a seamless process, within the same level). While this makes for some entertaining gameplay, it's not necessarily original. What I find to be original, is how the art style changes between 8-bit and 16-bit era inspired, depending on the time period.
[b]+ Music:[/b] Same as above. The music is worth listening to by itself. There are also two tracks for each timeline.
[b]+ Writing:[/b] I didn't find the story being anything to write home about, but the dialogue is exceedingly funny. The characters don't take themselves seriously, constantly breaking the 4th wall. Even the antagonists are endearing, in a way reminiscent of Undertale.
[b]+ Level design:[/b] Each biome introduces new mechanics that usually require you to get an upgrade at the nearest shop or to unlock it by completing a loosely defined quest line. These upgrades are not required to traverse all subsequent areas, but they make the process easier. One gripe that I may have is that despite these quality of life improvements, it can become tedious to run around a map trying to figure out what's your next objective (noting that the positioning of the fast travel portals are not always the best). Although that's partially my fault for not wanting to buy hints.

[b]- Second shop:[/b] You can access the shop via multiple portals scattered around the map. The shop is always the same, existing in a pocket dimension. At some point, you gain access to a second shop, underneath the first. There, you can spend the acquired currency on figurines. I don't really see the purpose of this, outside being a money sink for completionists.

The Messenger is a great metroidvania in many ways. The upgrades feel rewarding, the challenges are pretty well designed, the story is solid, the soundtrack is very solid, the graphics are acceptable...

So why am I not recommending this game?
Simple. The controls infuriate me.

To be precise, one single issue with the core gameplay has been the bane of my existence: The jump button does too many things that fight each other.
After about 4 hours of gameplay at most and a couple upgrades in the shop, your jump key will make you:
- Jump if you're on the ground
- Double-jump if you're in mid-air and have slashed an enemy before landing (cloud-step mechanic)
- Glide if you are in the air BUT do not have a cloud-step stored
- Do a tiny double-jump for recovery [i]instead of anything else[/i] if you have taken a hit because taking a hit mid-air makes you fall uncontrollably otherwise

I would like to reiterate: The list above is [b]on a single button[/b]. It's a mess. It's not even like the game has run out of controller buttons; in fact, it only uses one of the shoulder buttons and one of the triggers! But nope, instead the jump face button is a jack-of-all-trades mess and it has tripped me far too many times. Enough times that that corresponding button on my controller is now damaged which really didn't help.

I got tired of it by the time I reached the ending. I picked up some cheats, annihilated the last couple bosses, saw how much content was in their postgame extra parallel universe shenanigans, and I gave up.

My hand hurts, I probably need a new controller soon, and I'm mad I spent so much time on a game that was so close to being good but kills its harder challenges with controls that actively fight you.

Want a good metroidvania with solid controls? Just play Hollow Knight damnit.

Game fucking rocks. The gameplay itself isn't super special and overall isn't that challenging, but the writing, the music, the art, the self-awareness and pacing all make it so much more than just a ninja gaiden clone.
This game was made with so much love and it just oozes awesomeness at every point. I was halfway through the game going "I'm definitely going to replay this shit". And in the second half, the game opens up and goes metroidvania, and essentially asks you to replay the game. But now, all the levels you completed in 8-bit can be played in 16-bit and vice versa. It was an absolute joy to run through again with remixed graphics, music, and level design with all your unlocked gear, just tearing through areas while headbanging to kickass tunes. 

Favorite area was the cloud temple revisit. I think this was the exact point where I was completely in love with this game. The first time you visit with 16-bit graphics and music, and it's a very breezy run through blue skies and white clouds with a lighthearted SNES-style soundtrack. The second time, you play through in 8-bit with a raging thunderstorm in the background and the soundtrack turns into this hard-hitting chiptune remix that absolutely SHREDS. Occasionally you flip back and forth from sunny day to stormy night, and the contrast is fucking amazing.

I can't recommend this game enough. Making this game was clearly somebody's lifelong dream come true, and it is an honor and a joy to experience it.

125261810.review:
I played through The Messenger earlier this year, and it's become one of my favorite pixilated indie titles in recent memory. The game is a side-scrolling story-based platformer which feels like a spiritual successor to the old NES Ninja Gaiden games. The game starts out as a level based platformer but eventually opens up into a Metroidvania style game with lots of exploration and collectables. The Messenger also has one of the better time travel mechanics I've experienced in the genre.

123655213.review:
When I started playing I wasnt very impressed but as I played more and more The Messenger kept surprising me at every turn and now I can say with certainty that this game is fantastic.

THE GOOD

The sheer amount of things The Messenger pulls off successfully is staggering. I was never a huge fan of 8-bit visuals but it started to grow on me and then suddenly we are transported into the 16-bit future and my mind was blown. Next stop, turning a fun action platformer into a metroidvania with you constantly jumping from 8-bit past to 16-bit future in order to get new items and discover new passages. I have never seen anything like this before and it was pretty great. And then, just when you become sure that the game has no more tricks up its sleeve, it throws a dragon riding sequence at you. Amazing! 
Combat is very simple but when combined with movement it feels great. You'll be slashing your way across the map, cloudsteping off of enemy projectiles and grappling to both walls and enemies. Boss battles are also very well done and I found bosses to be way better designed and more memorable than in some boss-famous games. I'm also very grateful to the devs for including a very generous checkpoint system. While The Messenger is not too hard, some areas are quite challenging but nearby checkpoints made sure I never got too frustrated. 
Soundtrack is just cool as hell, thats all I'll say.
But the biggest surprise for me was the writing. While the story itself is merely ok with some demons and time travel sheenanigans, the characters and their dialogue are fantastic. There is a crazy amount of well written humor which I did not see coming. One character in particular, a certain shopkeeper, is 4th wall breaking, hat stealing, storytelling, closet loving bundle of sarcarsm. I love this guy and he should be present in every future project devs decide to do! Besides him, we have our slightly clueless protagonist, a dragon who wants to be a butler, necromancer skeleton thats very sensitive about his height etc. I love all these guys.
Final thing I'll mention is DLC, Picnic Panic. Now, I usually wouldnt include DLC in a review but Picnic Panic is FREE, adds a lot of content and brings more unexpected things to the table (SPOILERS: like making final boss into a boxing match, Mike Tyson Punch out style).

THE BAD

There are few things I found to be somewhat less good, though. Most are nitpicks but some did make quite a bit of problems in my playthrough.
First is the respawning enemies. Enemies respawn as soon as they are outside of your screen and not when you leave a room which I found annoying. It happens that you miss your jump and then land straight into a projectile from an enemy who was dead 2 seconds ago. I understand enemies and/or their projectiles are sometimes needed to traverse a room but rooms like that are few and far inbetween.
Now, most challenging rooms are definitely those that lead to power seals or some other items. While most of these are challenging in a fun way, a few are just hair pulling difficult. Thankfully, insane platforming skills are not always necessary and you can sometimes brute force your way through the room by tanking hits and fumbling your way through which gets the job done but...doesnt feel quite right.
Another negative is that you, as far as I can tell, cant skip cutscenes at all. Not very fun on replays, especially knowing there is a huge info dump at one point in the game.
My biggest issue is gliding/cloud step combo with both actions being tied to the same key. For the most part of the game its a non issue but in more challenging areas I felt very uncomfortable with this control scheme.

VERDICT

This game is so good. Its fun, challenging, got an awesome soundtrack and hilarious writing. I love everything about it..except those few annoyances I mentioned. Still, at some parts those little nitpicks made the game a very infuriating experience. Not very often, but sometimes. I am very excited for Sea of Stars now and I do hope Messenger 2 eventually comes because it does deserve a true sequel. Close to perfect, but not quite there.
9/10

Cannot recommend this game. Too many huge problems preventing this game from being fun, despite a good start.

Problem 1: controls. It is one of these badly designed games that keep adding one key at a time, each time a new move is unlocked, until you have to play with too many keys. In this case, it's extreme: FIVE different keys with the left hand (they are jump, fire type 1, fire type 2, fire type 3 -- not kidding, and another key to walk on water). This is just BAD design. Two keys are ok. Three can be necessary but usually mean "we didn't make an effort to improve the commands". Four is invariably terrible design. But five? Five is beyond. In this case, it would have been so easy to economize. You'll want the "walk on water" key always pressed. There is absolutely zero reason to not keep it pressed, at any time. It should have been automatic (you dive anyway if you stop moving so that there is never a need to depress that key). At a certain point I was tempted to ask a friend to keep it pressed for me. Hint: when your game becomes accidentally two player co-op, it means that game-design wasn't exactly your destiny. Economize on  commands! E.g. double tap the fire key to shoot. This sloppy design makes me think this game was not made with either hearth or brain.

Problem 2: difficulty curve. 99% of the game is easy/relaxing, but then there are these two stages that are 1000x more difficult than the rest. Most stages I could clear on first attempt, a few took 3 or 4 attempts. These two, they took 500+ attempts each. That frustrating and boring, and the player feels cheated because no other part required that level of skill or luck. The first one I endured. The second one made me quit. It was the biggest culprit, the 3rd power stone in the Elemental Skyland, where you are supposed to climb up to a power stone by hitting flames being fired at you. That's insane.
