118864390.review:
A really fun homage to the controller-breaking impossibility of the original NES Ninja Gaiden series.

At least for the first half.

POSITIVES:
-The platforming is very tight.  For those who are familiar with the original Ninja Gaiden for the NES, you'll be instantly familiar.
-Level design(again, for the first part) is excellent.  VERY nostalgic in terms of design and graphics.
-Humor is well written, for the most part.

NEGATIVES:
-How do you feel about pixel-perfect jumps?  Controls that dont' listen to you at least a 3rd of the time?  This is definitely the game for you if you like that kind of stuff.
-Bosses are average at best, boring and obnoxiously tedious at worst.
-Quarble.  I can appreciate the mechanic where Quarble technically "saves" you from death, but after the 400th time dying due to the fact that you touched a platform at the wrong angle and get sent back 14 rooms, and Quarble snarking "Gee, maybe you should try jumping" for the 4000th time, it gets real old real quick.
-The 1st half of this game works like a traditional 8-bit NES platformer, with specific levels and areas.  The 2nd half [spoiler]turns to 16-bit.  The graphics are definitely better, the animations are smoother.  But it changes into a Metroidvania, and a really boring one at that.  Too much backtracking for not enough reward.[/spoiler]
-2nd half has severe performance issues.  It becomes very jerky at times; I have to quit the game, often quit steam, and also restart my computer to get rid of it.

All in all, this game could've been so much more; It starts out being quite fun(if not frustrating); unfortunately it turns into a boring slog 1/2 way through the game.

118471880.review:
The Messenger is an ode to the classic Ninja Gaiden. Its particularity is to offer two styles of gameplay - the 1st third is, essentially, platform with 8-bit visuals in successive levels while the final two thirds consist of metroidvania mechanics alternating 8 and 16-bit scenarios.

The first part is pretty much perfect. There is a wide variety of scenarios, enemies and bosses, with an exceptionally well-paced progression in terms of introducing new skills and increasing difficulty. In parallel, the story develops properly and there are humorous NPCs. The experience is pleasant until there is a turning point in the plot.

Well, all the pleasant feeling fades away as the game becomes a metroidvania. Interactions with NPCs become increasingly rare, there are practically no bosses and new items to be collected witch represent significant changes in gameplay. It is true that the variation between 8-bit and 16-bit is a valid differential, including modifications to the - excellent - songs, but its benefit is nullified by the tedious backtracking, annoying repetition of enemies and the consequent progressive loss of engagement.

The Messenger is a clear example of a brilliant idea but poorly executed. It seems that all the inspiration was condensed in the first stage, being its continuity, except for really exciting moments in one of the new areas, dull. There are very high quality demonstrations of the implemented concepts, which, unfortunately, did not last over the 15 hours of gameplay, which ended with a bitter taste in the mouth.

- - - [pt-br] - - -

The Messenger é uma ode ao clássico Ninja Gaiden. Sua particularidade é oferecer dois estilos de gameplay - o 1º terço é, essencialmente, plataforma com visual 8-bit em níveis sucessivos enquanto os dois terços finais consistem na mecânica de metroidvânia alternando cenários em 8 e 16-bit.

A primeira parte é praticamente perfeita. Há grande variedade de cenários, inimigos e chefões, com uma progressão excepcionalmente bem cadenciada no concernente à introdução de novas habilidades e dificuldade crescente. Em paralelo, a história se desenvolve adequadamente e há NPCs bem humorados, em especial o da loja de upgrades. A experiência é agradável até que há um ponto de virada no enredo.

Pois bem, toda a sensação agradável vai se esvaindo à medida que o jogo vira um metroidvânia. As interações com NPCs tornam-se cada vez mais raras, há praticamente ausência de chefões e novos itens para serem coletáveis e que representem alterações significativas na jogabilidade. É bem verdade que a variação entre 8-bit e 16-bit é um diferencial válido, inclusive com modificações nas - excelentes - músicas, porém seu benefício é anulado pelo backtracking tedioso, repetição incômoda de inimigos e consequente perda progressiva de engajamento.

The Messenger é um claro exemplo de ideia genial porém executada insatisfatoriamente. Parece que toda a inspiração foi condensada na primeira etapa, sendo sua continuidade, salvo momentos realmente empolgantes em uma das áreas inéditas, maçante. Há demonstrações de altíssima qualidade nos conceitos implementados, as quais, infelizmente, não se sustentaram ao longo das 15h de jogatina, encerradas com um gosto amargo na boca.

The first time I have played this game was back there in 2019, during that period I experienced both slight interest in SNES-styled retro games (Thanks to AVGN) and a lack of motivation to complete any of the started games to the end, not because the games I played were bad, but because of the unhealthy lifestyle, which has resulted in almost complete inability to entertain myself.
I do not remember from where I knew about The Messenger, but I had immediately downloaded it and it just blew my head away, making me finish it in several big sits and immediately pray for a new DLC or sequel to be released. It is pretty much like your childhood dreams game coming true, when you were revisiting your favourite old platformer for the 10th time and thinking: «Oh, how cool it would be if there was a game about time-travelling demon-killing ninja fighting giant totem in the tropics». To sum up all the amazing stuff about The Messenger there are:
•	Amazing recreation of the classic old-school metroidvania experience, with smooth gameplay, challenging platforming and a unique idea of a transition between 8-bit and 16-bit dimensions.
•	Simple though charming setting, which is built with great love, combined with funny dialogues alongside smart and unexpected breaks of the fourth wall. And yes, the shopkeeper’s cabinet opening is one of my personal favourite WTF moments in the history of video games.
•	The soundtrack is completely worth its money even without the game itself. (Btw, check out amazing «24-bit» mixes made by «Temmie Plays!» on youtube, they combine the awesomeness of both 8-bit and 16-bit versions and they are long enough to listen to them while doing your stuff without constant repeat button spam ).
•	Astonishing pixel art, which is doing great in recreating a classic retro-platformer atmosphere and sometimes rewards you with pretty wallpaperable landscapes. 
•	Action-packed DLC which takes everything I loved from the original game and upgrades it, resulting in even more challenging platforming, new versions of enemies I just like to hate, and 3 new bosses, 1 of which (the totem) I consider the best in the whole game, and all of these in a Hawaiian style.
Despite such amount of positive qualities the game has its problems too:
•	It is a good platformer but a bad metroidvania. I guess that it is the only reason why some people are giving a «Not Recommended» to this game, but in my opinion, it is completely forgivable for this game, and here is why: [i] While creating a game which is basically a homage to old 8/16-bit games it is impossible not to sacrifice some gameplay properties to look more like such game. [/i] In 90-s, when resources for making games were limited, there just were no other options for some metroidvanias where we have to play as a melee character to make a not spam-click-centred battle system or to fill the world with tons of content like in a Hollow Knight. They also mostly relied on platforming, the same way this game does and does it great, so here I have no idea what complaints are about. Talking about this «transition» when a game turns into a metroidvania from a linear platformer I also do not understand what these backtracking-unhappy people expected from a game which is even tagged in a shop as «Metroidvania». I 100% admit that after playing the Hollow Knight backtracking here feels like a little bruh moment, but for me, it still was an enjoyable experience to revisit all of the locations to look at them in a 16-bit appearance and search for a power seals. And I am not even talking about the introduction of new cool locations such as Riviere Turquoise and Elemental Skylands.
•	Poor enemies diversity. The annoying but not so big problem of this game, which somehow can be partially indulgenced by my comment above (Like, I do not remember old platformers having 50+ types of enemies). But anyway the problem is real, and I wished to see much more location-unique monsters. The only such example in the whole game is the 2 types of mushroom monsters at the Quillshroom Marsh. Sad but true.
•	Gathering collectables is much more enjoyable than the reward. I liked the whole idea of the power seals, it was nice and challenging to find them all, but I had much more expectations about what the chest in the shop hides inside. Like, it still was ok, but I expected more. I could be much more satisfied if there was a key to some secret and super-hard location at the end of which we could have received the reward from that chest +golden character skin after equipping which we finally were rewarded with the best trophy – «Why are you gae»-like monologue from a shopkeeper being unhappy about modern videogame trends.
•	There are too few shopkeeper quotes after the metroidvania part of the game kicks in. That is just sad because this dude creates a huge percentage of the atmosphere of the game.
•	Tiny figures of not even all mobs from the game with a poor description are a lazy way to utilize not-needed time shards.
The only thing I can say in conclusion: I goddamn love this game with all of its imperfectness, because it has its soul and it was developed by enthusiastic and motivated people, the real Messengers – not because they tried to earn money on some product after some market analysis, but because they wanted to give us a story to enjoy, a message. And I think that the message was carried successfully, now waiting for the story to continue in the Sea Of Stars.
[b]I give this game 9/10
Thank you kindly for reading this one to the bottom!

115214083.review:
[h1]Expectations are everything[/h1]

First played it right after it was given for free by Epic over 2 years ago, among countless others in their still ongoing weekly freebie extravaganza. As one of high-profile indies, temptation got the better of me and I singed a deal with the devil. My excitement was short lived though and disappointment prevailed very soon into my adventure. I should have read the fine print before inking my signature...

There are two main and very 'in your face' issues this rather innovative spin on action platformers suffers from. First one are Shopkeeper's dialogues which are basically disgustingly cringe 4th wall nukage fests appealing to elementary grade schoolkids, and the other is unfortunate emulation of gameplay shortcomings arising from technical limitations of NES era. Every enemy and their projectiles disappear/reappear as soon as they re-enter the screen. When you kill an enemy it will be there when move out of frame and back again, joyfully shooting at you as if the last two seconds never happened. It happens EVERYWHERE by design.

My plan was to simply import old saves to unlock achievs and avoid further brain damage but devil had other plans. Against my better judgement I decided to play through it again before posting by far my harshest ban worthy review. For even the devil deserves a 2nd chance right? Well don't ask me how but mental preparation did something to me and I was able to tolerate both issues now and somehow enjoy the rest. Hopefully knowing that does the same to you.

* * *

It starts of as pretty promising Ninja Gaiden homage with very pleasing 8-bit aesthetic, music and well measured mix of platforming and combat. Difficulty and variety being just right, supported by a simple story of carrying an item to a sacred mountain to fulfill a prophecy. Straight out of '80s playbook. Soon enough you find your first shop where you learn you can upgrade your character a bit for Shards dropped by enemies (more health, damage resistance, ranged weapon, etc), stuff that'll make progress easier basically.
Shopkeeper is kind of a meme character as his main purpose is to make fun of the genre by excessive text dumps and preachy moral stories. Both are optional but c'mon who wouldn't exhaust every dialogue option? I can tell you each and every one can be skipped at no loss whatsoever (Lightfoot Tabi + Jump buttons skip all text at hyper-speed!) but topics about Level Area, Ability, Weapon, Boss should be read at least once for story sake.

This goes on for about 10 Level Areas filled with enemies, secrets, collectibles, bosses, and shops which btw double as a save-point. You'll need the latter as deaths can be frequent depending on skill ceiling, mostly due to insta-death pits and occasional traps, combat is surprisingly forgiving considering era it's emulating. Areas are pretty diverse and interesting, each with own catchy music (my fav being Bamboo Creek). Worth mentioning is music becomes muffled when you submerge and adds to generally polished experience.

Soon after reaching the summit at around half-way point game switches to 16-bit aesthetic and looks closer to a modern platformer! Every bit of asset is faithfully recreated in high fidelity including sound. Even more unexpectedly at around 2/3 it further expands into a Metroidvania. For that item you were carrying all this time was actually a Map.
This lets you overview the whole world you've been traversing, revealing countless missed secrets in fairly easily readable map. Main goal turns into finding additional 6 items delivered by cryptic objectives, how much depends if you paid attention to environment. Shopkeeper expands its inventory with more goodies at this point and world becomes saturated by 8/16-bit points where you can flip aesthetic which in turn affects room geometry to unlock previously blocked paths. Pretty neat.

What I liked the most is overall care put into world cohesion and gameplay mechanic. There's a lot of little details to keep you interested for more. Even the story is okay when you exclude Shopkeeper as other characters rarely suffer from being obnoxious. Progress and difficulty is well paced, with handful of spikes regarding certain collectibles, but nothing that can't be brute forced.
Boss fights are also among the best I had. Challenging but fair and more often than now you'll have enough time to adapt to changing attack patterns on first attempt before getting brutalized. Later on in NG+, if you took 'THE DEAL', you'll slice through them like hot knife through butter. That was extremely satisfying btw!

DLC can be accessed after beating main Boss and reloading that save again. It's characterized by harder version of base game with emphasis on platforming and lots of death pits. It's good but controls are not as tight to support complex movement patterns.
New Game+ isn't just tacked on but offers [url=https://the-messenger.fandom.com/wiki/New_Game_%2B]rarely seen[/url] extra content and challenges. This is where game became really fun for me and I played even after getting all achievs, something I rarely do if ever. Felt great plowing through base content like a speed-running God with my old transferred gear and newly acquired DLC skills :)
Of course you'll be dieing a LOT with penalties so severe it would result in aneurysm for where it not a simple file save-scumm trick.

* * *

Besides witty but still very annoying Shopkeeper and NES combat limitation which I learned to deal with there isn't much to whine about. But it's unlike me to leave this section empty so here goes.

Metroidvania part is somewhat lacking in new player abilities. Only one is found and enables highly circumstantial walking on liquid. Other items you found only serve one-time purpose and send you backtracking on insufficiently densely placed fast-travel points. Most of late-game frustration comes from backtracking and not knowing where to go. Although there is an option to buy yourself out of the problem it requires time consuming money grind, in an otherwise well balanced economy. As a completionist my problems solved themselves by exploring the whole map and filling gaps but those wanting to just get it over with may get stuck in last quarter.

This also ties with with map design. Although easy to read for missables, its simple single color rectangle room design makes is practically impossible to discern which room it is and its individual configuration. Leading to false information when you finally get there and even more backtracking.

I also wish developers quit emulating NES-like stuff down to every detail and create a modern quick save/load/restart mechanism for those not wanting to put up with last century state-of-the-art. Just to load the damn game you have to sit through slow menu slides and endless blinking confirmations when you just want to redo last section ASAP. Latest save is kept in memory btw, so hard game restart is required to load safely backed up scummed save. Someone please tell them to quit this nonsense practice.

* * *

Crazy how giving it a 2nd chance completely turned me around and left me wondering where else that happened without me even knowing, not only in gaming but in life in general. It is what it is though and who knows, maybe a 3rd playthrough turns me around again, making me right the whole time? For now it's an easy recommend just know what to expect.

Basically, knowing that information means you would just choose the easiest most profitable level and plan on collecting all you can then intentionally dying, over and over again. I don't know.

Next, let's talk about boss mechanics, some of it is memorization which is okay I guess, but almost every time the bosses use a new move on you it's a sure thing you will take damage because it's a surprise gotcha attack that you would have had to know about before hand as there is no time to dodge. That being said, I really don't believe there is any amount of innate talent, or cautious technique from a skilled player that could get through the game without falling victim to the gotcha deaths. Falling from high places and having to redo a long sequence of jumps. Please limit these situations...

Flying enemies: why can they fly through walls and why can you not slash diagonally or up? I can't believe in the history of games we still haven't realized that backing up strategically so that the flyer eventually lowers its level to yours so you can hit it with a straight on attack is terrible because it breaks the game flow. Man, I'll tell you Zubat really did a number on the gaming industry, seems like every gamer is conditioned to love and hate bats. Game designer memes: it's not finished until i make the bat mobs. hehehe. I'm not asking for the moon here, and there's already a crouching slash. Just basic QoL stuff.

Also, maybe I'm just not that far yet but... if I'm a ninja is there no dash attack? Imagine I'm about to be hit and I know I can't avoid it because my walk speed is to slow but it's a long drawn out telegraphed thing, that's really no fun at all. It's just something that you can't stop but you're forced to watch and endure like the Oscars on TV. But if there was an opportunity to use skill to get out of that situation, then it would open the door for more options and exciting gameplay and allow for a higher skill ceiling. In a platformer, mobility is everything

I really do respect this game for it's very cool retro feel, the menus, the dialogue boxes, the pixel art, all are actually amazing. And I get that it's trying to recreate something like shinobi or  ninja gaiden or whatever for the original NES but sometimes being too faithful to the original is a bad thing, like in movies adaptations have to be made (cue the haters, lol). I think the magic of that era can still be captured (including the difficulty) without also porting the frustration factor and stiff controls in full.

If the game devs ever read this: please just put in ledge climb up. please take away that awful air technique, it's just unnecessary. It's momentum very rarely outperforms cloud jump + [spoiler] rope dart (grappling hook) [/spoiler].

The music, it is fine generally, but that same tune gets very grating, there needs to be more variety. Again, the idea of being fully married to recreate the NES style hurts here as the music is then less expressive. The music doesn't always have to be in your face, crazy adrenaline action music. It can sometimes be slower, atmospheric and relative to the environment the character is in. Even if the music still sticks to the chiptune style, it can become more expressive and the volume needs to be attenuated with more crescendos and decrescendos to improve the tone and don't be afraid to use the triangle wave for a longer smoother sustained voice.

Anyways, there's so much potential in this game, but maybe a sequel could be made and another chance would be had to redo some mechanics and gameplay ideas.

And just so you don't think I'm a super duper hater, things I love about this game:
-basically every piece of art, the bosses especially the big ones are so cool, the backgrounds, the fading, the menus, dialogue box, and the shop (my favorite place in the game hands down).
-the dialogue is very good, story is to the point and cut all the fat, great. The shop dialogue is hilarious and in good taste
-the objectives are clear, how things work is very clear
-most of the boss themes

114393397.review:
The Messenger is a love letter to old-school action-platform game fans who dig solid mechanics, pattern-based enemy placement, and fluid level design. The front half of the game is a fast-paced, linear adventure taking you through some of the best pixel art of the modern day. Once you think you have the game beat it opens up even further, letting you shift between the past and present to engage you in some intuitive puzzle solving. Once you think you are surely at the end of your adventure the game unfolds once again for another reveal that turns your linear adventure into a sprawling Metroidvania. 

The front half of the game, with its scripted nature, flows better than the back half of the game. But when you go into the back half (which has very little hand holding), just think of it as a huge jungle gym where you get to flex your platforming skills and all the awesome moves you've opened up along the way as you search for power seals and music notes to open up the end game.

Outside of a couple pacing issues in the Metroidvania section, the overall experience is heightned even more by one of the best 8 and 16-bit inspired music scores in the "modern-retro" movement along with some truly charming writing that makes you bust out laughing when you least expect it. Make sure to talk to the Shopkeeper often, asking him to tell you stories. There are some real zingers in here. 

The Messenger isn't perfect - but damn near, especially if you like retro inspired action-platform games. While the pacing in the back half is a bit uneven, it doesn't ruin the experience in the least because there are plenty of new areas to discover and amazingly satisfying platforming challenges to get the remaining power seals. 

The development team has crafted a wonderful world to inhabit with great character design, awesome platforming, stellar music score, fun mechanics, and a sprawling narrative that is far deeper than you are set up to believe. If you even remotely like platform-action games in the vein of Ninja Gaiden or Mega Man, DO NOT pass this up.

[h1]The Nessenger un metroidvania con encasas habilidades de bactraking que no por ello lo hace ser mediocre.[/h1]

La cantidad no siempre es lo mejor, en este caso aplicamos esa lógica para decir que The Messenger funciona perfectamente con tan "solo" 1 habilidad para explorar de nuevo todas las zonas. [spoiler]Hay otra "pequeña" habilidad que es la de andar por agua y lava que solo funciona para zonas muy concretas, pero que son igual de importantes si quieres avanzar en el juego.[/spoiler]

[b][u]PLATAFORMEO[/u][/b]
Básicamente este apartado junto a la exploración son lo que hace el juego divertido, si bien no debes dejar que te de una mala impresión por los primeros niveles del juego por su dificultad para niños de 6 años ya que luego se va poniendo más interesante mezclado partes pasajeras con partes desafiantes (sin llegar a los niveles de dificultad de Aeterna Notics) e incluso un poco de pensar (más que nada observar tu alrededor por unos segundos más de lo acostumbrado). La mecánica para explorar después de pasado cierto punto de la historia lo hace una experiencia refrescante ya que aunque pases por muchos sitios que ya estuviste lo hará en su mayoría de veces ser una experiencia única de nuevo. Un dato que pueda ser interesante por si a mas jugadores le pasa es que hay muchos lugares de vértigo, cosa que a mi a pesar de tener vértigo hasta en los juegos (si te sorprende no lo digo en broma) pude jugarlo sin problemas eso si a veces con algunas pausas de lo tenso que estaba.

[b][u]HABILIDADES[/u][/b]
Aquí vamos a lo importante del juego junto al plataformeo, y es que a pesar de que exista "solo" una habilidad es más que suficiente para tenerte totalmente enganchado porque es una manera totalmente diferente a la que nos tienen acostumbrados en todos los metroidvanias, todas las habilidades que te dan son únicamente para progresar linealmente, hasta cierto punto del juego no podrás desbloquear la opción de explorar de nuevo todas las zonas (dejando de ser un juego lineal) y cuando seas capaz tendrás una única habilidad de backtraking que estarás usándola todo el tiempo y en todas las zonas. Si no te gusta juegos "desplazamiento horizontal 2D" que no sean metroidvanias y por lo tanto quieres lo clásico de desbloquear poco a poco habilidades tipo doble salto, dash, etc y es lo único que crees es la única formula que funciona no lo compres (si te gusta los juegos de plataforma, sin dudarlo), pero yo por mi parte te invito a que lo pruebes que tampoco es un juego caro, yo soy fan del genero a lo clásico como muchas habilidades y que cada una sirva para explorar toneladas de lugares secretos con puzzles, plataformeo y de todo; y The Messenger me a dejado más que sorprendido y satisfecho.

[b][u]COMBATE[/u][/b]
Aquí es donde más flojea el juego, los enemigos prácticamente todos de 1 hit están muertos excepto 1 [spoiler] por su logro[/spoiler]. Es un juego enfocado en la exploración y plataformeo por lo tanto la única dificultad en ellos es saber esquivarlos o eliminarlos según el caso para que no molesten. A veces (no siempre pero diría que es bastante habitual) son usados para algo más ya os daréis cuenta si lo jugáis. Importante aclarar que aunque este apartado no sea el más "elaborado" de todos el combate es muy fluido.

[b][u]JEFES[/u][/b]
Poco diré aquí para no hacer spoilers, solo comentare que son extremadamente fáciles, algunos solo con darle un poco al cerebro y veas la forma en la cual los desarrolladores tenían pensado que hicieras ese jefe lo harás sin problemas ya que de por si llegar a esas conclusiones no son para nada complicadas y aplicarlas son igual de fáciles. Si intentas ir a lo bruto si que podrás morir alguna que otra vez. Entonces la pregunta del millón ¿que gracia tiene entonces implementar los jefes? Lore y [spoiler]poder avanzar en el juego[/spoiler], son divertidos si no eres un obsesivo de la dificultad de extrema y pueden ser una forma relajante y divertida de amenizar el juego después del plataformeo, que algunos tienen su aquel.

[b][u]HISTORIA[/u][/b]
Una historia que parece tirar a lo cliché al inicio y que al final te dará más de una sorpresa y momentos bastante graciosos. No tiene un lore muy extenso y es lo suficientemente interesante para dejarte con las ganas de terminarlo. Como siempre esta parte es es muy subjetiva pero considero que no es mala y aunque no pueda gustar a muchos es innegable que es bueno.

La parte artística y banda sonora no veo la necesidad de comentar nada ya que es puramente gustos, si estas leyendo esta reseña te harás una idea el tipo de banda sonora que te espera y también viste por las imágenes como es.

108094747.review:
The Messenger is a retro-styled side-scrolling platformer with a couple of tricks up its sleeve. You play as a young ninja who, in line with an ancient prophecy, is tasked by a legendary hero to deliver a mystical scroll to the top of a high mountain as part of mankind's eternal war against an army of demons, only for it to turn out that you've let yourself in for more than you bargained for.

While the game is overall very good, it has some flaws that I should probably touch on first before I explain what makes the game worthwhile - while they weren't a big deal for me, they might be for others.

This one might be kind of a spoiler, but then again not really because they more or less show it wholesale in the trailer: the game is a linear 8-bit style platformer for a good while, but once you hit a certain point in the game it throws two curve balls at you. First, it changes the graphical style from an 8-bit style to a 16-bit one, and then shortly after it reveals that the linear game you were playing actually has an open map that connects the levels together like a metroidvania. It's a clever twist, but I think that it wasn't implemented as well as it could be. Typically in a metroidvania style game you're hunting for items and powerups that both allow access to new areas as well granting you upgrades and new tools that increase the strength and versatility of your characters. While in this section you will be hunting down items, for the most part they're just keys that are only useful in getting past very specific obstacles, and don't really give your character any kind of powerup or new abilities, with a single exception to the rule. It's odd because the game does have upgrades of this kind, but they're either given to you for free while the game is still linear or bought for crystals that you can gather anywhere in either phase of the game. I think maybe the devs should have held back at least some of the movement abilities like the climbing claws, wingsuit or rope dart until the metroidvania part of the game to make it a bit more engaging, though the design of large parts of the first half would have to change to accommodate that. While there are new areas to visit during the second half of the game, it also feels short on bosses when compared to the first half. Overall it kind of feels like the game has peaked when the linear half has ended and settles into a bit of a lull in the early parts of the metroidvania, though things pick up again as you near the finale. Overall I think that if you're eyeing this game because you're a fan of metroidvanias and this one has the metroidvania tag on it, maybe reconsider before buying (though there are other good reasons to get this that I'll get into.)

One other thing that's a mixed bag is the game's writing. This is a very tongue-in-cheek kind of game, with 4th wall breaking jokes abound. Most of these are at least amusing but it can get excessive at times, especially when there's a serious enough story underneath it all about the curse afflicting the world and your role in the grand scheme of things. Of course there's always time for humour even in a serious story, and it's not like the jokes are unfunny, but it sometimes feels like the balance here is off. The worst offender is Quargle, your little demon buddy who's pulling double duty as an explanation for how you can continue when you die as well as your penalty for death. He eats a certain amount of the crystals you gather shortly after you respawn, but that's not my real problem with him. My real issue is that he shows up to taunt you in between you dying and respawning. This becomes annoying very fast because A: his jokes by and large aren't that funny and B: you'll probably die a lot in this game, especially if you suck like me. He just amplifies the aggravation that you might start to feel if you're struggling with a tough platforming section or a hard boss. At a couple of points the game teases the prospect that they might do something with his character but ultimately he ends up just stuck in his role as an irritation. The other characters, thankfully, are at least less annoying and for the most part better written. There are a couple of real standouts, especially the blue-robed shopkeeper and a handful of other memorable minor characters.

While I've just spent a while talking about the game's flaws and mixed parts, I still strongly recommend the game. This is because despite the game's difficulty and the flawed parts, it's just immensely fun overall. The game's controls are great and the levels are expertly designed. Even the parts of the metroidvania that should be kind of a slog aren't because the game's platforming controls and level design make even the act of backtracking through areas engaging and challenging. You start out with your basic jump and the ability to swing your sword, with the one gimmick of being able to gain additional jumps in midair by landing hits on enemies and certain environment objects with your sword before you land. To this the game adds a ranged attack, the ability to climb on walls, glide, and grapple to climbable walls and enemies with a rope dart. Then the levels demand that you combine these abilities together to conquer a gauntlet of obstacles that are often demanding but incredibly satisfying to conquer. The game also demands the same skills from you in its boss fights, all of which are very fun and probably the highlight of the game overall.

All of this is emphasised by the game's excellent presentation. The game is distinctly retro-styled, but in the good way where it's evocative of the old style of 8 and and 16 bit games, but absolutely superior to the way most of them actually looked thanks to many subtle improvements. It's quite similar to Shovel Knight in that way. The game's soundtrack is comprised pretty much entirely of bangers too. Both the graphics and sound are yet further enhanced by the game's final distinctive gimmick - you'll have already experienced the switch from 8 to 16 bit by the time the metroidvania begins, but that aspect of the game is yet further enhanced when it reveals the fact that you can repeatedly change between the two styles during ordinary gameplay by passing through time portals. The two graphical and even sound styles change from one to the other utterly seamlessly, and the effect is really impressive, but not only that, you'll be required to do it in gameplay to solve puzzles and progress in the level, because the layout of the level is often different in the other timeline. They could have built the entire game around this gimmick, but in my opinion they use it just the right amount, where it's there just enough to make you think and add some additional complexity to traversing the levels without becoming intrusive or obnoxious.

Overall you do need to have the right expectations when going into this - just because this game has the metroidvania tag on it you shouldn't come in expecting Hollow Knight or something. What you are getting on the other hand is just a very fun and challenging platformer with great retro visuals and sound, and a decent story despite some potential foibles in regards to the consistency of its pacing and tone. Hopefully the devs come back and either make a sequel or at least another game like this - the game has a free-LC chapter playable postgame that's more of the same excellent gameplay but with clear signs that the developers have learnt from the shortcomings of the base game.

En The Messenger tomamos el papel de un ninja que debe llevar un pergamino esencial para la salvación de la humanidad, adentrándose en un viaje a través de un mundo devastado en donde le esperan muchas amenazas. Una historia llamativa acompañada con un muy buen sentido del humor a través de sus diversos personajes.

The Messenger es un homenaje a la joya de Acción y Plataformas que fue Ninja Gaiden mezclado con el gran genero Metroidvania, un gameplay absorbente, dinámico y bastante clásico con su estética 8 bits y 16 bits. Un gameplay pulido y un diseño de nivel confortable con una dificultad decente, ni muy fácil ni muy difícil. 

El pixel art es BESTIAL, tienes una gran variedad de entornos que puedes apreciar, el aspecto de los personajes tampoco se queda corto, tienen muy buenos diseños y unos memorables jefes. Realmente parece un juego de NES, si te gustan los juegos retro, entonces este es tu juego.

El único punto malo que puedo dar sobre The Messenger es que durante una parte del juego se puede volver algo tedioso, pero no a un punto en donde la experiencia del juego se vuelve super tediosa o mala en si, simplemente es un poco de pereza. 

En lo personal se a convertido en uno de mis plataformas favoritos, su gameplay, su estética, su sensacional banda sonora superaron todas las expectativas que tenia sobre The Messenger, un juegazo que recomendaría a cualquier amante de los Plataformas. <3

Great action platformer with metroidvania elements. Definitely worth checking out if either of those things are up your alley.

The Messenger is rather light on the story side of things and features a very small set of characters, but the interactions you have with them are hilarious and thoughtful. Lots of witty banter accompanied by surprisingly deep life advice, and The Messenger isn't afraid to poke fun at itself. The visual aesthetic is carefully crafted, with each area feeling distinct, and the soundtrack is an instant classic. Combat is simplistic and nicely complements the fluid movement system. Movement really opens up after a few upgrades, and the...uh...grapple hook...quickly became one of my favourite tools.

In terms of difficulty, we can break that down into (1) knowing your objective in the game, (2) platforming, and (3) bosses. As for (1), there can be moments in the game where you aren't sure where to go, but it turns out you can expend some in-game currency for a clear sense of direction if you don't feel like figuring that out yourself. I think that's great. The platforming (2) is straightforward for the most part, but I can see how it would be tricky if you're new to platforming games and aren't super comfortable bouncing off things for a while without your feet touching the ground. I was pleasantly surprised with the level design, it's some of the funnest platforming I've tried to date. Definitely a few tricky sections, but those were a welcome challenge and never got too frustrating. I can't really say the same for the bosses (3). If I had to estimate, I'd say about 33% of the bosses were too easy (early game), about 33% of the bosses were the *perfect* mixture of challenge and fun (late game), while about 33% of the bosses were just unnecessarily frustrating (mid-game). In particular, there were a few boss arenas with insta-death mechanics that really pushed my patience, especially when they seemed to take forever to kill. The worst offender though was a boss who would, in his final stage, move to a location where he could only be hit by ranged attacks. That would be fine, except for the fact that you're only given a finite number of ranged attacks. So if you miss all them, then you have to restart the entire fight, and cross your fingers that your timing is better next time. All that said, it's worth emphasizing that the ~33% of bosses who are good are *really good*.

I'm happy that I finally gave The Messenger a try after having it on my radar for a while. Exceeded expectations overall, and I would look forward to a sequel.

[h1]The Messenger (No Spoiler) Review[/h1]
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Overview[/h2]
The Messenger is the most fun I've had playing video games in a long time. It's not every day that I find a game that's a challenge to put down every time I play it. Everything about this game is fantastic: the art, the music, the controls, the dialogue etc. This is why it pains me to say that the Messenger has a few glaring issues that would've ruined the game if it wasn't so fun to make up for that fact. Despite this: don't think, just buy this game.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Story[/h2]
In a small village of ninjas lives the last surviving members of humanity. One day, a legendary hero arrives at the village to stop the demon king and gives our main character a scroll that he is tasked with bringing to the top of a mountain. The story unfolds as you play the game in some pretty interesting ways. Despite having a solid sense of humor, when the game attempts to be serious, it succeeds. My only problem is the game doesn't feel like it had a satisfying conclusion. You play this entire game to save your village, and you don't even get to see what happens to them or the other characters you met after you defeat the final boss; the game just ends.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
The gameplay is where this game really shines. The Messenger has some of the tightest controls and interesting movement options I've ever seen. The grappling hook and glider especially create great momentum that makes movement have weight. The cloud step is also a blast to use (hitting enemies awards you an extra jump) allowing you to stay in the air for a long time and makes combat especially satisfying. The bosses are some of the most creative I've ever seen and finally beating them after memorizing their attack patterns is quite fulfilling. This is also true to the rest of the gameplay, with each death making me eager to get back where I left off. The game also has a unique way of respawning, with a debt-collector character following you around and taking the money you collect instead of lives. Like Celeste, it makes death feel a lot less frustrating. But the coolest part of the gameplay is the time travel mechanic- allowing you to switch between an 8-bit style and a 16-bit style, which is travelling 500 years into the future in in-game time. In some places, they use it super creatively (like in the butterfly boss fight, the magic fireflies, and the differences between the future and past of several areas); and for most of the game it just unlocks different passageways. The optional collectibles provide some pretty challenging rooms and is rewarding to get them all. The special item it unlocks is awesome without being overpowered. And while you can't get it until almost the end of the game, you get to use it in all of the free DLC. My only [i]very[/i] minor gripe is I felt they could've done more with it and sometimes getting to a certain area in a time period can be annoying. 
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Art/Music:[/h2]
Speaking of the time travel mechanic, the art in both styles is just so cool. After playing the game only in the past in the beginning, seeing areas you've already traversed in 16-bit is awesome. The 8-bit style reminds me of Shovel Knight and the 16-bit style is straight-up beautiful. I cannot describe how awesome the soundtrack is. Each area has bopping music, and changing the "instruments" used between the future and past was a nice touch.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Dialogue/Humor[/h2]
The messenger has a pretty good sense of humor, mostly coming from the shopkeeper and the death screens. While some dialogue comes off as a bit cringey, it really grew on me. There're lots of meta jokes, and the shopkeeper's stories were genuinely interesting. So make sure to chat with him as much as possible when you go to the shop. The death screens have some funny degrading jokes from the debt-collector character which are amusing for a while. It's definitely not for everyone, but I enjoyed it.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]My Big Issues[/h2]
Easily the biggest problem with the game is fast travel- or lack thereof. The game starts out linear, and this part I would consider masterpiece game design. That is still present when the game becomes a metroidvania, but is spread thin by egregiously long backtracking. This could mean you have to travel half an area just to get to the one you need to get to. I ended up going through half of the Autumn area like 6-7 times to traverse the map, to the point where hearing the music (once one of my favorite tracks in the game) became ear grating. Once you need to look for the music notes, you only get hints ("prophecies") to go off of. These are easy to misinterpret, and you could travel an entire area to find a music note and then realize you were wrong about what it meant. This is heartbreaking to me because it would be [i]so[/i] easy to fix this issue. Simply have fast travel points at all of the portal checkpoints and spawn there in the last time period you touched it with. Prophecies are super cryptic, and finding out what they mean could be made a lot easier with an encyclopedia with important pieces of dialogue written down on it and details about each area to consult later. I'm not going to remember those after not playing the game for a week. And for my most minor issue: the money sink. I get it was a joke, but it bothered me that the money wrench (what you need to unlock the time sink) costs equal to the amount of money you have. I didn't discover it until I had been collecting time shards for a while and had almost 3000 time shards that I had to lose for a joke, preventing me from buying toys in the money sink. It's a cool idea though.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Overall[/h2]
The Messenger is a masterpiece- no exaggeration. It has some of the best game design I've ever seen, and is ridiculously fun to play. Once you power through the backtracking sections, there is magic to be found throughout the whole game. This easily cracks my Top 5 games of All Time list. Buy it on sale or not- it's well worth it.

[h1] The Messenger is one of the best "old-school-like" games I've played recently. It starts off as a great 8-bit styled platformer, with clear inspiration from the NES Ninja Gaiden series. Thankfully, it's not nearly as difficult (i.e. frustrating) as those games were but overall a fun little gem. What it does - does it well but there are a few things that frustrated me. [/h1]

The game turns into a great Metroidvania game. And it's a really good one. I mean, on some level, it doesn't really do anything new, but it just does it all so well. I still have a few gripes (I always do), so I'll just mention them in passing during the review.

The controls are tight, but I wish the floating mechanics were not as easily confused with the double jump mechanic. Although that may have been a deliberate decision for level-design reasons.

The graphics are great. The boss designs are also awesome, animations are fluid, and the scenery is unbelievable in the "16-bit" version.

Level design is really good, secrets are just hard enough to find, but not painfully obscure as to be frustrating. One thing that deserves mention is the humour. Decent non-toilet humour with good timing, I mean, when's the last time I saw this in a game? It made me laugh multiple times simply by being funny and not "over the top".

Despite the positive aspects there are definitely things I did not like. The first half of the game contains roundabout 12 levels after each one and it was fun. That was the best part for me but after that when "The Prophet" started - it went downhill - atleast for me. The forced metroidvania aspect was unnessecary and visiting the same areas multiple times because of "a riddle" is also something I did not enjoy. Why isn't there 1 teleporter per map-chapter? Why do I have to go to Place C in order to Reach B because B doesn't have a fast travel point? That made the game unbelievable frustrating for me to visit multiple parts of the game 10 times or more simply because of this and it didn't need that at all.

All in all, I can't recommend The Messenger enough, despite that big con.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]

★★★★★ Story
★★★★★ Visuals/Graphics
★★★★☆ World Design (Universe, Lore and Artwork)
★★★★☆ Level Design (Environment and Space)

★★★★☆ Combat, Equipment and Enemies
★★★★☆ Side Quests
★★★★☆ Errands (Minor Side Quests)
★★★★☆ Certain Movement Mechanics (e.g Mount, climbing and swimming - I found myself often grabbing a wall instead of falling down so minus 1 star for that)
★★★★★ Certain Characters and Dialogue
★★★★★ Quest Rewards

So with issues like character control and methods of movement as they are, it's starting with a core that's more prone to failure and problems if you try to give it challenges requiring fine control and quick accurate movement of your character. Every so often, A game comes around that reminds you how fun gaming can be and why you started gaming in the first place. 

The Messenger was on my radar for a long time but I was worried that the Ninja Gaiden inspired gameplay and retro aesthetic would feel out-dated and boring to play. I was so wrong! The controls are tight and the movement is intuitive and satisfying. The game starts you out with limited abilities and lets you discover new ways to move, without holding your hand, through brilliant level design akin to Mega Man X. The game constantly evolves as each new ability gives you new ways to approach obstacles and the amount of care and detail put into each stage is evident throughout.

This game is a 2D action platformer that evolves into a metroidvania. It appears very linear and short at first, but later reveals itself as a much larger game with enough depth to keep you occupied for hours on end. The gimmick that everyone is familiar with, is the ability to switch between past and future, which also switches the game between 8 bit and 16 bit graphics. But this ability is more than just a gimmick to switch aesthetics. It adds another layer of strategic depth to the game that keeps the stages feeling fresh when the metroidvania style gameplay calls for the player to traverse stages that were once completed in order to discover something new.    

The characters in this game are unexpectedly hilarious and continuously break the fourth wall to communicate the self-awareness of the devs and the tributes they're paying to classic metroidvania titles, ninja gaiden, 2D platformers and more. The story ebbs and flows, expertly weaving in great storytelling, with tension and comedic relief. The game handles progression well and never overwhelms you with things to do, and yet, it somehow still gives you the freedom to make choices and complete the game in whatever order you wish.

The Messenger takes classic retro platforming and injects new life into it. The level design is nothing short of spectacular and the different level mechanics sprinkled throughout the game will keep surprising you and challenging you in unexpected ways. This game feels very familiar and yet very fresh. It does so much with so little, once again proving that passionate game design and attention to detail can create an exciting and fresh gaming experience without the need for modern graphics.

I couldn't put this one down until I had finished a full playthrough and I'm tempted to dive back in again. The Messenger is fun, challenging, funny, satisfying, endearing and addictive. It had me blown away by it's intelligent level design and creative use of game mechanics. It had me in stitches laughing at it's amazingly self-aware humour. At times it had me wanting to throw my controller across the room in frustration, only to win me back when a moment of clarity allowed me to execute the perfect combination of well-timed moves to complete a challenging section in the most satisfying way possible.

I can't recommend this game enough. It truly is a special title that I will be raving about for years to come. Well worth the price of entry.

This is one of the most fun games I've played this year! The level design and graphics remind me of some NES-era classics such as Megaman and obviously Ninja Gaiden. If you like retro Cave Story like graphics, linear Megaman-like levels and a bit of Metroidvania influence, you really should play this game.

LEVEL DESIGN
The levels are way too much fun to play! After a certain point in the game, you get to explore previous levels in a new way, kinda turning it into a Metroidvania. Some people dislike this aspect, since the levels themselves are pretty linear. I kinda like it, but frankly it doesn't add too much to the game - the levels continue to be pretty linear, you just go back to them with a few twists, in order to get some stuff you missed. I think it's pretty fun to revisit the old levels, but I wouldn't go as far as to call that a Metroidvania.

MUSIC
On a scale of 0 to Celeste, this game gets a solid 9 for the soundtrack. It makes the gameplay even more enjoyable. It's the kind of game where you catch yourself playing the music in your head even after a few days off of it.

ENEMIES
Enemies are the one bad point in the game for me, though. They are very boring, some of them only stand still spitting fire, while others just run blindly from one side of the screen to the other. There's only two enemies that react to you besides the bosses, and I think this is a missed opportunity to introduce some fair difficulty in the game.

DIFFICULTY
Not a hard game. It's very fun to play and you won't get frustrated out of dying too much. And even if you die too much in a certain spot, there's almost certainly a save point waiting for you as soon as you get through the obstacle.

HUMOR
Although the humor from this game is not for everyone, I actually laughed out loud at some dialogues. They REALLY enjoy breaking the 4th wall in this game. The Shopkeeper is a pretty funny guy, too. You can tell that the developers actively tried to insert as many funny stuff as possible in this game.

All in all, this game was a great find, I'm very glad I bought it!

This game emulates the 8-bit and 16-bit experience a little TOO closely, in my opinion. Right down to grating music and graphical glitches. Enemies forget they are dead the moment they leave the screen. Menus are clunky and annoying to navigate. 

And if you die, you may have to backtrack through 2 or 3 rooms to get back to where you were.

Those are just minor complaints, however. I have two big complaints:

---

First, the game doesn't speak a consistent "language" when it comes to exploration. 

For example, sometimes you can climb up a wall off the top of the screen and it will take you to a new room. Great. Other times, you climb a wall, expecting to go to a new room at the top and you are greeted with invisible walls you can't grip, or you bump your head on something off-screen. Lame.

Even worse, there is this graphical pattern they USUALLY put above pits that lets you know you will die if you fall down them. If you're sharp and notice the pattern is missing, you can sometimes find secret rooms. Great! But SOMETIMES the death-pattern is missing, so you jump off expecting a secret room AND THEN YOU DIE ANYWAY. 

W. T. F.

If falling ALWAYS made you die, it wouldn't be a problem. But it's inconsistent. And they've littered secret Power Seals all over the place, so you have to be attentive and explore every nook and cranny to find branching paths. 

Random beatings totally kill the spirit of exploration and curiosity.

---

Secondly, they overload the control scheme too much. This is the biggest reason I'm giving this a "Not Recommended."

A jumps. While in the air, you can attack something and then hit A again to jump. So far, so good. It's a clever system, and I like it. There's also an upgrade that restores your jump when you get hit. No problem there.

But then you get an upgrade that lets you glide by, guess what, hitting and then holding A in the air. Not only that, but you can't simply hold A to jump and then glide. No, you have to explicitly press A a second time while in the air and then hold it. If your jump gets restored mid-air (because you hit something or got hit), it's impossible to glide without using your jump because they're on the same button.

You might see where this is going. There's too much stuff on A. With all those conditions attached, it can be hard to predict what your character will do when things get fast-paced, leading to frantic button-mashing.

For example, you might hit A and hold it, expecting to glide, but you just fall instead because you forgot to press A a second time. Or you might hit A and hold it to glide, but it actually jumps without gliding instead because you attacked something recently. Or all you want to do hit, jump, hit, jump, but you keep randomly gliding when you don't want to.

Did I mention that gliding changes the direction of your attack, which can make you plummet to your death because you missed what you were attacking so your jump didn't get restored?

What a mess. The optimal strategy is to mash buttons and hope for the best. I hate it.

They could fix this by assigning Glide to a different button. And just making it always glide when the button is held down.

There are other things I hate about the controls, too. Like if you press left or right and then jump while your analog stick is angled even a TINY BIT down, it might make you drop off a wall instead of jumping—or drop through a thin platform. Really unexpected.

---

Anyway, not everything is bad about this game. The grappling hook is quite fun, for example. Some of the dialog is clever. There's enough bad that I can't recommend it, though.

When I opened the Messenger for the very first time, I heard, saw and felt that 8bit classic UI and music and I was surprised at first but then no more, but rather I became nostalgic and impressed by how the game starts off and by its UI especially and even the initial cutscenes which were made using the same technology, that kind of intro made me feel so relaxed and at ease, it was very nice. Fast forward a few minutes to when you get to play and that feeling of relaxation becomes a feeling of anticipation, excitement, and eagerness to just see more and just play the game, it was a mystical way to start a video game and sure enough, the more you want the more the Messenger provides!


To start things off, I just want to say that this game is incredible, great in almost every way a Metroidvania can be in my opinion (a balance between being a platformer and a Metroidvania). The music in this game steals the lights and charms the audience, it's so energetic, fitting, and vigorous and I think the music alone deserves its separate review.

The Messenger wants you to finish your mission with a smile on your face and it does that by having a beautiful sense of humor throughout the game, entertaining NPCs, and the famous shopkeeper, the cornerstone of our mission.

As a ninja, you are tasked with an impossible task, to BE the messenger and do what messengers do, to deliver a message, to carry meaning, to create hope, and to accept responsibility, and I think one - arguably important - way to interpret the message of this game is how a team's hard work can pay off and how creatives we humans can be, such as the people behind this game because the Messenger is the embodiment of creativity and beauty.

When you play a ninja game, the expectations of the game should be to feel like a ninja and to play like one, and surely it's the case here, the movement is swift, smooth, and keeps on changing and evolving. Now you add to that some of the best dramatic, absolute fire of soundtracks, and you have got a gem of a video game in those two aspects on your hands. The music just goes way too well with the gameplay it's a miracle of a combination in this regard.

The Messenger is all about moving fast and doing ninja stuff in a world where time and space are relative, and with how Metroidvanias work in terms of upgrades and progressing, I found myself set for what I called in this game the "when I thought I was out, they pulled me back in" experience which was kind of my experience, every time I thought that this game can't possibly have any more content or do any new stuff the game would just prove me wrong one time after another and that was done always in such a refreshing manner that it's nearly impossible to feel stale or bored throughout the game.
To think about that how those small indie games have such a significant amount of content and a full of life content with no repetition or blind duplication makes you think about what are the big and AAA companies doing out there?

The Messenger takes place in many environments and worlds, and it varies in its difficulty based on the world you are in. The Messenger is an example (among others) of how good those genres are, it's truly incredible how platformers and Metroidvanias are always surprising me game after game of how good they can be, I feel happy as  I write this review, I feel happy for having played the Messenger and I feel happy for being a fan of those genres.

[h1]Review[/h1]
While The Messenger may look like your regular ”indie game inspired by the classics at first”, the complete package easily surpasses that expectation. This is mostly because the argument can be made that the game changes how it progresses halfway through. At first, it already satisfied me with a platformer that had fun level design, boss fights that kept getting better, and especially the smooth controls that feel satisfying to master. Upgrades to the kit of our ninja were relevant at all times, all working together to make cloud stepping work very well. And the game also gives you enough opportunity to master the mechanics, with minimal punishment on death and unlockable abilities that… may be a bit too helpful, and also very cheap to unlock with the in-game currency. Halfway through the game however, progression switches from a level-to-level basis to a 16-bit Metroidvania with time travel. This gave us the ability to revisit all of the levels but in our own desired order, which was generally fun to do as they hadn’t seen just a graphical upgrade, but entire layout changes. However, the Metroidvania aspect of the game isn’t very good, mostly due to the world being linear instead of interconnected, forcing us to go through entire stages just to reach a destination. It also didn’t really give much of an incentive to explore beyond the required story-locked upgrades that are only used in a specific part of the world. Granted, I did still have a lot of fun exploring these levels again, especially with the reward gained from the free DLC that, in its own right, was a fun experience for those looking for more content from this game.

99383989.review:
This game took a while to grow on me but once it did it really took over until I could finish the main story and watch the credits roll. Its hard to remember what I didn't like about the game at the outset, other than it felt like another throw back ninja game with platforming and old school boss fights. I liked the way the story was playing out and everything, but it didn't suck me in.

Fast forward the better part of a year and I picked the game up where I left off, right about in the middle of a difficult area where I needed to go in a direction I'd forgotten, and do the thing with the stuff. Within about 20 or 30 minutes I'd decided the controls really were super responsive, the world was just challenging enough to be hard but not mind-numbingly difficult, and the music was a nice touch.

This game wasn't really what I thought it was going into it, and there are likely plenty of other reviews that either praise or lament the fact that at some point the player's experience changes. So let's just say if you want a super linear story line with no sense of humor and just generic game play, look elsewhere.

What you're getting into in The Messenger is half platforming combat and half puzzle / treasure hunt. There's fun upgrades that make the game both easier and your character more able to get around in the world, and there are plenty of difficult sections if you want to test out your skills. As noted, the controls are good and it's few and far between the moments you can blame anything other than yourself and your own game play for a death.

Biggest gripes are that some of the things you're asked to collect through arduous skill puzzles aren't really worth it, and that if you're not dying a ton you can upgrade everything reasonably early on. The game isn't reliant on, and does not in any way need, the special items you can get, so just playing through and making sure your base gear is as topped up as you'd like it is enough. 

Buy this game if you like 2d, retro style platforming games, especially because this game has looks from the NES and SNES era, a soundtrack to match, and will scratch that itch. The combat isn't the hardest thing ever, but some dedication to actually knowing how to use a 2d sword helps. You'll enjoy this game if you give it time to do its thing, are great at getting around in the world, and if you use a controller versus say, keyboard and mouse.

Don't buy this game if you don't like dying a bunch if you're not a platforming pro, if you're not into retro style games, or if you don't like having a fetch quest in a part of the world you've already been to. You'll be asked to do some back tracking, and if you have zero patience for anything this one might start off too slowly to keep your interest.

If one was going to summarize the message that's being delivered here in this game it would likely have to be something about how games can entertain you and challenge you even if they look like they're a throw back to another era.

Sabotage bills themselves as a team dedicated to making modern games that remind us of what we loved about games of the 80s and 90s, and if you're old enough to remember playing the NES and SNES when they were new, you'll find a kindred spirit in the people at Sabotage. 

The Messenger does very accurately evoke what a great NES/SNES game felt like, but is also bursting with creativity and original ideas, fulfilling Sabotage's mission of bridging retro and modern. You probably already know the central conceit of The Messenger - the fact that it shifts from 8-bit to 16-bit and back again- and the 8-bit portion really does feel like a great game from the NES era. The 16-bit portion really does look and feel like a great SNES game. The way they're married together, the mechanics involved, and the game's self-aware meta-referential sense of humor are distinctly modern. 

As I said, this game kept surprising me. Every time I thought I knew what it was, it twisted again. But what really keeps you going forward is the action platforming gameplay. Showing that they do truly understand classic games, Sabotage knows that what really makes games fun is that they're.. fun to play. Fun comes first. The Messenger starts out with quite a simple set of controls and commands, and slowly adds more and more complexity with new abilities to suit new obstacles. Then it mixes and remixes everything you've learned to keep challenging you. The controls become intuitive, and you continue to adapt to new environments. 

I found the difficulty to be pretty much spot-on. There were both platforming challenges and boss fights that took me many tries to complete, but always seemed doable. The game is not easy, but not unfair. Most of the time, it took me just the right amount of time to pass a challenge room or a boss. 

This truly is a love letter to classic games, but it is not short on new ideas. Sabotage's follow-up, Sea of Stars, currently in development, shows the same sensibility; a deep love for classic games, along with a trove of great new ideas. Looking forward to seeing what these guys do in the future. These guys really get me, and I really get where they're coming from.

[h1] 𝕀𝕥 𝕚𝕤 𝕪𝕠𝕦𝕣 𝕥𝕦𝕣𝕟 𝕥𝕠 𝕔𝕒𝕣𝕣𝕪 𝕥𝕙𝕖 𝕤𝕔𝕣𝕠𝕝𝕝, 𝕞𝕖𝕤𝕤𝕖𝕟𝕘𝕖𝕣! [/h1]

Something terrible happened to the Ninja Village during a normal, "training day"... As you, a nameless ninja, are training with your friends, having fun, throwing shurikens at one another, you hear a THWAP... and then suddenly, everything you've ever known changed in a blink of an eye. DEMONS, invading your village, killing your friends, and just as you reach for the Ninja Elder, he falls down with one last request... To take a scroll to the highest peak. As you're saved by a hero, you embark on a journey that's serious... Seriously hilarious haha! It actually is.

You play as The Messenger, a nameless ninja who's tasked with taking a scroll to the highest peak... And as you're doing that, you might feel frustrated because of paths you cannot reach, or pits you can't jump over to see what's on the other intriguing side... Do NOT fret, as the game is split into two parts: The first part is a linear platformer while only after beating a Demon General do you actually see the game for what it really is: A MASTERPIECE. You also meet an enigmatic shopkeeper that is specialized in jokes... and he's as comic as he is mysterious -- Well, he will also upgrade your talents for Time Shards. Gameplay-wise, the game involves, at first, a lot of grappling hooks, a lot of climbing, a lot of slashing demons, throwing shurikens and obliterating bosses... Then comes the second half with the game-mechanic that actually changes the ENTIRE gameplay: Timeshifting... You'll find yourself timeshifting to reach those high places and discover more collectibles. Also, to advance the second half of the game, you'll have to switch time then find key spots to gather some key items and prevent some terrible events to happen in the Future; the future that you can then shift into and go see these events NOT unfold. 

The pixel-art is something to behold here; it's amazing and helps contrast the Past from the Future as when your Ninja is in the past, the graphics look more like NES, while when he goes to the Future, they are more like SNES graphics. It's really well-done.

This game is the best pixel-art platformer I've had the pleasure to play on Steam. It's a 10/10 game and I got it full price and have NEVER regretted it. It's an underrated gem with maybe a clichéd story but very original mechanics and environments that change with time. Also, the Shopkeeper is funnier that most "comedians" these days, it also helps that there is no voice-acting. One could just say that the game was perfectly made. Definitely will look forward to a sequel.

A neat idea but lots of little things ultimately bring it down.  This review has some SPOILERS.

The first half of the game is a pretty good Ninja Gaiden-like game, but the second half is kind of a poor metroidvania that reuses the levels and enemies of the first half.  Except those mostly linear levels were designed for a different kind of gameplay, it just doesn't work in a metroidvania style.  You get only one new traversal ability in the second half and it is used once outside of the level where you get it.  This is a problem because good metroidvanias make traversing old areas again fun by giving you new traversal abilities or changing the enemies.  This doesn't happen here and all that pointless backtracking you do in the second half is a chore as a result.

The bosses all tend to have long phases where you can't damage them.  So you just end up waiting (sometimes minutes it feels like) for the chance to deliver a few attacks before you get stuck in the no-damage phase again.  This makes the fights feel rather long and repetitive.

The writing is pretty good and a lot of the jokes land well, but there is little dialogue in the second half of the game, and the final boss is introduced in an agonisingly long lore dump cutscene just before the final dungeon.  It almost feels like the final boss is the writer's DnD character he insisted on plugging in the game because it doesn't relate to the rest of the adventure at all.  It would have been more elegant to weave in little bits of this mystery into the narrative instead of dumping it all in one shot at the end.

There are 45 special power seals to collect in the game.  Some of those are very obnoxious to get.  Once you have all of them you unlock a better ranged attack.  No cutscene or anything.  And it's so close to the end of the game that you will have few opportunities to use it.  It was a completely letdown.

So as you see there's just a ton of little things like that that sour the experience.  I really wanted to like this game and I'm a big fan of including a Québécois langage option, but I was ultimately left pretty disappointed.

The music is really awesome though.

95082853.review: Basically a spiritual successor to the old school Ninja Gaiden games. Has a good sense of humor, amazing music, and really awesome sprite work for both the 8-bit and 16-bit versions of the world. Solid game play albeit a bit difficult at times. My two biggest issues with the game is the amount of backtracking you have to do to get 100% and how after fully upgrading your gear, money stops having a real use. About halfway through, the game becomes a metroidvania, giving you free reign to explore all the areas, uncover new ones, and gives you some fast travel stations to help get around. My issue is that the fast travel hub only has 6 stations and this is simply not enough IMO. The fast travel points are spread out pretty far apart in the world so, sometimes you'll have to backtrack through one or two whole levels just to get to an item you couldn't get to before. At first it isn't so bad but by the end it really starts to drag. As for the not having things to spend money on, around half way into my playthrough I was able to fully upgrade everything. The game acknowledges this and jokes about it, adding a literal money sink to the shop, wherein you can spend money on little figures of enemies that get displayed in the shop, a neat addition but, still not worth spending money on. The game does this a few times actually, where it will acknowledge a flaw the game has and joke about it, but doesn't really fix the flaw. Another example being the shopkeeper makes a joke about the wall climbing claws and how sometimes when you're trying to just fall straight down you'll cling to the wall instead. Not a huge issue, since overall the game is very polished but, I do find it odd that they didn't just fix these issues instead of making jokes about them. All in all, its a very solid game, the highlights being the visuals, the soundtrack(Seriously the music is godly) and the dialogue, while the backtracking is probably the biggest issue I have. Would give it a solid 8/10 if I had to rate it, and I think even at full price for $20 its worth picking up.

I was genuinely surprised by how much I liked this game. I had the luxury of playing the game completely blind, because I bought it on Humble Bundle, looked at two or three screenshots, then decided to redeem it. What I thought was going to be another cheap indie pixel platformer turned into one of the most fun games that I've played in years.
I'll say this, if you find the game interesting from the screenshots alone, don't bother reading reviews, you'll get MUCH more out of the game playing it knowing as little as possible.

The graphics are very similar to something like Shovel Knight where they mimic the old retro styles, but updating them ever so slightly. Making them look like how we think we remember an old NES game like Ninja Gaiden looked like back when we first played it.

The gameplay is insanely solid. One of the best feeling platformers I've played in a long time. My only issue is with the wall climbing. There's one glitch that happens frequent enough that I tried to avoid wall climbing as much as possible: Sometimes you just get stuck, you can jump off and reset, but it just feels bad when you cling onto a wall then hold up, but just stay in place when you're in the middle of the wall.

Now, probably my favorite part of game was the music. I'm not a music critic so I don't really have the vocabulary to explain why I like the music as much as I do, but what I can say is that, outside of Hideki Naganuma's work, I haven't actively searched out the soundtrack for a game like this since Dustforce.

My biggest complaints mainly just come from the DLC. I didn't like the surfing minigame, the totem boss had an instant kill that roadblocked me for almost a half hour, the last half of the DLC just isn't all that fun to play, and the DLC unlike the main game wasn't designed as a metroidvania, but instead as a normal linear platformer. That being said, the final boss in the DLC is amazing and I'd argue is worth trudging through the DLC for.
