94357566.review:
That's it.  I'm never jumping again.  I think I've fallen into more pits here than in every other game combined.  

Big pits. Little pits. High pits, low pits.  

[i]Pits of lava and pits of ice, pits with blades that rend and slice.  

Drowned in rivers of pristine blue, and sank in bogs of quicksand, too.  

Crept carefully 'round the pits of slime, yet still fell in them every time.

I'd scaled mountains, touched the stars. 

'Midst twists and turns I'd climbed so far!

Yet slid upon the snow, and then

I plummeted back down again. [/i]

I remember playing Ninja Gaiden when I was a kid.  I died a lot in that, too, but it kept you going with cinematic cutscenes which were pretty novel for the time.  The story made you want to find out what happened next, which helped you to push through all of the cheap deaths and level restarts.  Point is, if you're going to make a punishing game--especially these days, when there are so many options--you've got to give us a good reason to stick around.

I'm not so sure they do that here.  

They don't even really tell you what's going on until the very end.  The rest of the time it's all just played for laughs and the characters you meet are only there to deliver fourth-wall-breaking riffs, like one of those Twitter threads where everyone's trying to show off how snarky and clever they can be and nobody cares about anything they're saying.  It's a very self-indulgent sort of style.  

Look, if you want to make a retro tribute to Ninja Gaiden or something, then just do it, keeping in mind that those games at least tried to tell real stories that fit the nature of the setting.  That's what Axiom Verge did with Metroid.  You don't need to keep reminding us how savvy and genre-aware and above-it-all you are.  Yeah, there can be comic relief, but it's supposed to be exactly that: a break from otherwise meaningful events.  When every character is a joke, it just spoils the immersion.
  
Or if you want to go the other route and make an affectionate parody of old video game conventions, that's fine too.  In fact, there's a brilliant idea perfectly suited to that purpose at the heart of this game: using different eras in graphics to tell a time travel story.   (They should have focused on that and explored it much further.)  Then you can be as wacky as your heart desires; but in that case you really need to stay in better contact with the player.  It's hard to maintain a light, funny vibe while you're sending us off to the pits for long, lonely stretches of torture.  

There's a part near the end when all of a sudden they take off the clown nose and expect us to sit through a long straight-faced cutscene, and all I could think was, "wait, am I supposed to be taking this seriously now?  It's a little late for that." 
     
These two sides of the game clash terribly with one another. They don't go far enough either way to commit to a course, and as a result never manage to find their voice.  It's too bad, because this really is a creative and ambitious game.  You can only hold players at an ironic distance for so long, though, before they start to lose interest, especially when you're beating the @%#& out of them with your other hand.   

For all the self-conscious irony of the story, the gameplay is all business.  It starts off so easy that you wonder whether that's part of the joke, too; but after a while the difficulty goes through the roof and mostly stays there.  Their main thing is this ability where you hit stuff in midair and spring off of it to jump farther.  You're going to be doing that a lot, and most of the tougher platforming sections revolve around pushing it to the extreme while giant pits yawn beneath you.  

You do see quite a bit of improvement in your skill over the course of the game, but overall the challenges feel like they're more about memorization and setting you up to fall into sneaky traps than straight-up pushing you to master a set of abilities.  It dampens the sense of any payoff for all of your efforts, like no matter what you do they're going to find a way to screw you.    

For example, there's one level where you have to escape from this huge monster and if you hesitate the slightest bit at any point you have to start all over.  It's filled with obstacle after obstacle, all calibrated down to the micron to trick and frustrate.  

You'd expect that kind of deviousness in a slower-paced puzzle-platformer, but in an action game like this--especially once you have to start backtracking all over the map--it ends up feeling like you're spending hours in stop-and-go traffic.

The results speak for themselves.  I was once a sane man; but fall into one too many pits, and next thing you know I'm rhyming like Dr. Seuss to vent my frustration.  

[i]Now gather 'round and hear the lesson of my sorry tale:

All ye who seek to play this game must be prepared to fail. [/i]

94094866.review:
A very good platformer. You can tell a lot of heart and soul went into this game, but not all is positive.

The art and music are fantastic and the general gameplay flow is smooth. You move, you jump, you have a melee attack and can throw a shuriken. If you hit an enemy while in the air, you get an additional jump and this can chain infinitely. It's a speedrunners dream and moving through the stages and levels is fun.

Halfway through, the game suddenly transitions into a metroidvania, and that is where it gets annoying. To progress (and find collectibles), you need to do a lot of backtracking, visit the same screens over and over and just generally waste a lot of time walking. Fast travel is only there in limited form, so that means, again, more walking. My question though is: why? I mean, the game was fine as a linear platformer. Why does it have to transition into a metroidvania(-like) halfway through?

It doesn't even make much sense. You only get one additional ability during that time that only opens up one thing. The only reason you can now get collectibles you didn't get previously is because the time portals now opened up, and some paths are only open in one time. I feel like that isn't really the point of a Metroidvania - isn't the point of those games to get earlier collectables or paths that you couldn't previously get by using later equipment or abilities? There is a clear structure and inspiration of those games, but nothing in place that made those games fun.

The jump from linear to open world is somewhat jarring and doesn't add too much to the game overall, aside from two new areas. It just seems to pad the game length for no good reason, as the game is somewhat short even with that in place. It took me about 8 hours or so to finish the game with all collectibles and even getting stuck at one point, as one of the items you need to continue is not at all obvious and you either need to use Google to figure out how to start the process or get lucky. Or pay ingame money for a hint, I guess, though I did not try that.

Overall, the game is really good, but it does have a few frustrating points. The gorgeous art and music and flowing gameplay contrasts harshly with the pointless metroidvania-like second half (with all the fun of those kind of games removed) and some frustrating boss fights that stretch on for too long, especially later on. I would still recommend the game, as a lot of work and love was clearly put into it, though I just wish that care and love extended to the second half too.

92272410.review:
At first this seems like a pretty average 2D side-scroller that aims to thrive on the nostalgia of people that played 8-bit games like Ninja Gaiden back in the day, but don't be fooled. It is much more.

It tells the story of you, the "messenger" chosen from a ninja village when the world is threatened by a demon attack. You have been given the task to deliver a scroll to ultimately save the world. 

As you traverse along the world, you pick up some necessary abilities and fight some bosses. These bosses have some nice designs, but some in the first areas are pretty simple.

Now where does this game stand out? For starters, the dialogue is hilarious. The shopkeeper NPC in this game has incredible lines and stories that have legitimately made me laugh out loud. The shopkeeper is one of my favorite NPC's in any game, probably just beaten by Sans from Undertale. The self-aware humor is great and just what I love. It's only sad that these conversations with the shopkeeper seem to diminish towards the end of the game, where they happen only sporadically.

The OST is great and it sounds just like old 8-bit tracks. Especially the one for Quillshroom Marsh, which is so fire that even the mushrooms in the area start singing along to the song sometimes (lol).

!Spoiler warning past this point!

Now this is great and all, but where the real love for this game comes from, is that it literally switches genres about halfway through. Yes. At the point where it seems like you're going to defeat the final boss, the game becomes a metroidvania. You travel into the future and then, the game switches from 8-bit to 16-bit. Now from this point on, you can go back to the areas that you have already traversed to pick up quest items. There is even a hilarious scene where the shopkeeper reveals that the scroll you were set out to deliver was actually the map for the game.

In the areas where you've already been, there are now these portals that let you switch from the 16-bit future to the 8-bit past and vice versa, which means that they had to make the entire map twice. Incredible. The way this was implemented had me saying "wow" to myself for some minutes.

The metroidvania aspects of the game are very well fleshed out and some boss fights even incorporate the dimension-switching which was really slick. 

The Messenger is an incredible indie experience and I can't believe I didn't review this before, as this is a sleeper hit, and I'm HYPED for Sea of Stars, developed by the same people that made this, set to release in 2022.

In conclusion, the way this game just blew me away and surpassed my expectations will forever stick with me, as this is a top-10 game for me (at least as of right now) 

If you want to try out a great indie game, give this a try. You won't regret it.

9/10

Great 2D platformer with snappy, responsive controls. Paying homage to the legend of the past Ninja Gaiden on NES. It has very witty writing with a lot of "4th wall breaking" elements, intertwining game mechanics with the story, which actually surprised me, as I followed the story more closely than I usually do in this kind of games, as I’m more of a mechanics kind of guy, who doesn’t care that much about the plot.
The difficulty level/ curve is, I would say, right in the middle, or maybe slightly above, as I didn't find it hard to progress. It never really made me grind the levels, but on the certain points I had to retry couple more times that I would like to admit, until I learned how to do it properly. The game never felt unfair and my character deaths resulted more from me making mistakes, rather than something forced by unjust game design. Which actually made me want to learn and master the game more. The bosses are fun to challenge, with attack patterns being clearly defined, so you don’t have to pray to Rngesus, just git gud. Maybe some of the early ones being a tad to easy.
Going back to 8/16 Bit graphic style is nothing new at this point, but is very well done and has a fantastic music to match, with a fun new gimmick to top it off.
Overall The Messenger feels like the definition of "labour of love", as it is done, in my opinion, by people who understand what an essence of fun was in 2D platformers with “metroidvania” elements in it, with old mechanics refined and some new ones added on top of that. I purposefully don't want to go in to details, as I had great joy going in blind on my first playthrough.
Having said all that praise I should probably point out some bad stuff, but honestly it is really hard without being nitpicky. I think if you don't like this "wink, wink, nudge, nudge" sense of humour or you don't like games that require you to learn by repetition, or maybe you require the game to handhold you through it and I really mean arrow pointing the way all the time kind of handholding, because you have in game tools to help you find what to do next (no drawing maps on piece of paper required), then maybe you won't like it. Otherwise a beauitful gem of a game.

This game is not perfect, but it experiments with various genre elements really well, and isn't afraid to do some fairly risky stuff (for example, having a boss fight that is just a Mike Tyson's Punch-out loop).

There were only a handful of times when I felt annoyed during this game (one of them being the Voodoo Totem boss -- the HP was perhaps too high and the mechanic transitions were too slow, so the boss fight felt extremely boring -- and thus dying became pretty frustrating). Baring these few exceptions, the game is really well balanced. 

The Messenger starts out as a fairly straightforward (and solid) Ninja Gaiden-like platformer, but then it opens up into a metroidvania-style game; at first, I was really put off by this transition, and actually stopped playing the game for a while (it just wasn't particularly gripping at the time). However, upon returning to complete it, I found myself having quite a bit of fun tracking down the various secrets and items in the game. 

The DLC is a nice addition, but it is very light on content and it introduced the Voodoo Totem which is by far the game's worst boss fight. The DLC was free content [u]and[/u] it was solid, so, really, one can't complain much.

The game's story was fine. The humor was hit or miss -- sometimes they relied too much on the kind of silly billy humor that is typical of the clinically unfunny (I'm sorry, but I don't know what to tell you if you think "do the thing!" is funny. It isn't). The game itself is very absurdist -- which is fine, I just don't think it was well executed. So, by the end, I found myself skipping all of the dialogue. In all honesty, had they simply forgone 80% of the dialogue, this aspect of the game would have landed a lot better for me. It felt like they were looking into the camera and winking at the audience every chance they got, which gets old fast, and the game is by no stretch short. 

The game's art direction extremely good; it expertly straddled the line of being playful and cool.  

Overall, The Messenger is an enjoyable experience, and worth the full price of the game -- an absolute steal if it's on sale.

This has quickly become one of my favorite games ever, no lie. I originally got it on Epic Games store for free, but bought it again on Steam for Steam Achievements (and to support the company). I also Kickstarted their next game, Sea of Stars. 

Semi-spoilery review follows

The game starts off as a standard left-right platformer that seems to be a homage to Ninja Gaiden,  but quickly distinguishes itself in its own right. The 8 bit music is amazing, the shopkeeper has hilarious (and philosophical) dialogue options.

As your journey progresses you get more skills (like a wing-suit, a grappling hook, and more).

Once you get to the Tower of Time level, however, things start to get interesting. You go 500 years in the future and the 8 bit graphics and music get upgraded to higher quality 16 bit graphics, like you went from Nintendo to Super Nintendo. Same with your character, he gets a fun new sprite. Go a little bit further however... Just when you think you might be at the end of the game... suddenly its a full Metroidvania. You get a map, time portals that switch between the past and future, a bunch of hidden secrets to find, and new power-ups scattered around the map that require thought and full use of your accumulated abilities to get. 

It's a pretty epic game, the writing is great, the plot is great, the level design is great, the music is great. I really don't know what I can say that's negative about this game....

90934273.review:
A Retro *and* Super Retro adventure

I’ve only played a handful of games that don’t reveal their true design until a pivotal moment hours into the experience. The Messenger proved that expecting a run of the mill side scrolling experience from developers that know exactly what makes such games go from good to great was a mistake I was happy to discover I made.

From the outset, The Messenger appears quite rudimentary as far as gameplay is concerned. Story wise, it’s not what I’d call ‘original’, but it’s definitely a nice twist on a tried and true formula. Some sprinklings of humorous meta-dialog, some 4th wall breaking, and other surprises were a nice touch. If you’ve played a side scrolling platformer/action game from the 90s you know exactly what to expect… 

Until you don’t.

Once the gorgeously animated and visualised pixel art environs soak into your brain, the game seamlessly genre-flips along with a fresher aesthetic coat of paint, which is tied directly to the narrative – it’s excellently put together and had me slow clapping at a point. There was still room to further explore the idea of mashing the separate aesthetics together mechanically, but suffice it to say that it was totally unique and like nothing I’ve really experienced before.

What the game absolutely nails, however, is the music. An absolutely gorgeous soundtrack that is everything a chiptune/Sega Megadrive fanboy would love - thematic, diverse, nostalgic to the max. It’s easy to see it was an integral part of designing The Messenger, something I found really elevated it above other similar offerings.

The experience is definitely a love letter to games of the era, with flavourings reminiscent of Super Metroid/Castlevania, and side scrolling action games like Shinobi. So with that, you should expect back tracking, some serious platforming, some cool boss fights and secrets/hidden rooms to discover.

Once you’ve finished the game, you have the option to jump back in for NG+ for an added challenge and an opportunity to collect things you missed the first time, plus a few extra bonuses, but after 15 odd hours, I’d say I’ve had my fill.

A hidden surprise of a game that took me far too long to get onto, with layers of design depth I never considered before.

8/10

My only gripe with The Messenger is how it tosses a lot of exposition at you right near the end in an attempt to make its final arc feel relevant to the rest of the story. Besides that, it's a nearly perfect game and I wholeheartedly recommend it.

90659596.review:
In a world where there are plenty of 2D pixel indie platformers, The Messenger does a fantastic job of distancing themselves from the masses with an interesting premise, fun and deep gameplay, catchy music, interesting and funny characters, and a lot of heart. Not only does it do this fantastically well, it also keeps surprises hidden that will continue to keep you chasing bosses and secrets until the final credits roll, and even further into the free DLC expansion offered up.

As most other reviews (and the game's description) will tell you, The Messenger is deceptive with the original style of game being a 2D platformer being thrown out the window only about 4 hours into the game, maybe a bit more or less depending on your skill level. It then takes this simple premise of going from screen to screen in standard 2D platformer fashion and flips that concept on its head, turning the game and all the previous areas you've explored into a full-featured metroidvania where hopping between time rifts teleports you from the past to the future and back again all while making minor changes in the world that might require a specific time period. It continues to expand as well, as there are more areas to unlock after you make the jump to metroidvania, so you aren't just retreading the same ground as you already did. Most aspects to the gameplay change are really interesting, from the improved graphics to higher quality music and more, with The Messenger doing a really good job of making both time periods. There are also some fantastic setpieces and bosses that play with the time period hopping, some of which are visual feasts just as much as they are skill tests. However with this change, while extremely interesting and to my knowledge, unique, is one that I also feel is pretty polarizing. There is a certain charm to the game that is a bit lost by the fact that you may need to backtrack through certain sections over and over again, and the game doesn't feel as well-crafted as a proper metroidvania does at certain times and there absolutely is a kneejerk reaction of annoyance for sure when your next objective is two areas away from the nearest fast travel portal and not even a new area at that. Its not all bad though, as exploring some of these previous areas in the future time period offers a surprising charm that alleviates some of the woe, and even exploring other newer areas in the past time period offers the same charm.

Apart from the issue of backtracking and the oddly infrequent fast travel points, The Messenger has a few flaws, but none of which that I would say should stop anyone from experiencing this game. My only other real gripe with the game comes from the fact that I think that the game suffers a small amount from not being built from the ground up as a metroidvania since there really is only one type of collectible throughout the game, and there are no secret items to collect or secret upgrades to keep you exploring every corner. In fact, you can buy an upgrade with in-game currency that reveals all the collectible locations on your map, pretty much pointing out the only real reason to truly explore. These collectibles do serve a purpose however, unlocking a special upgrade once you've collected all 45 in the game. I did go out of my way to do this, and unfortunately I can't really recommend doing this outside of completion/achievement reasons, since the upgrade isn't nearly as worthwhile as I expected it to be.

Despite some flaws and twists that change the game for the better or worse depending on your view, The Messenger is a uniquely fascinating game that really plays with the notion of what modern "retro" games can really be. It definitely deserves all the praise it gets and I think sets an extremely solid groundwork for what a potentially phenomenal sequel could be if the rough edges were filed down just a bit. Anyone who's interested in this game should definitely take the leap and experience one of the most interesting experiences in the modern retro wave and I definitely recommend it wholeheartedly.

This game has a variety of wonderful locations, nice pixel art, good music, and platforming that's unique and reward skilled players by opening up more possibilities on how to get through a map if you're skilled enough. The writing is funny, and there's an interesting twist partway through that adds a bit of puzzle solving to some sections. There's extra challenges to get collectibles if you really want to push yourself, and there's actually a suitable reward for doing so. I think it's pretty neat.  

However, I can't ignore the multiple poor experiences I had with this game. Slight spoilers ahead, this game becomes a metroidvania at some point, and expects backtracking. I don't mind backtracking too much, but the way this game handles it is extremely poor. 

First off, there's very few fast travel points. Half the areas in the game don't have one, you have to travel to a nearby zone and walk. This includes places that are mandatory to visit more then once, but nope, no nearby fast travel point.  

Second, the world isn't really cleverly put together like it needs to be for it to work. You don't unlock very many useful shortcuts, and often the map doesn't tell you but there's plenty of sections where it looks like you can get somewhere by your map, but you can't, it's locked or impassable. Combine that with very few fast travel points, and you've got to replay 5~15 minute sections you've already done multiple times to get what you need done. And that's if you don't end up running into a brick wall. Yeah, running into things you can't get past is common in a metroidvania, but this game seems to revel in making these annoying sections leading up to the impassable wall, so you waste time going there, probably waste time figuring out there's no trick and you just need an item (yes, it's not always obvious that an item is absolutely required), and then you have to waste time going back to a checkpoint with a shop. On top of this, the twist often ends up adding some extra annoyances to getting to certain sections.  

Third, your upgrades don't really make early sections that much faster, they're still a chore to navigate. Sometimes you can be a bit clever and make a section faster, but it's up to the level design to let you, and too often it doesn't. On top of that, this game loves instant death mechanics. Crushing, falling into pits, lava...that's not really a "bad" thing for a linear platformer, but for a game where you're backtracking a lot? That can quickly get annoying.  

It's not a bad game. There were a lot of cool sections that I enjoyed. I just think the game trips over itself in the second half, and becomes very annoying when it didn't need to be.

88381312.review:
The Messenger is a great platformer / metroidvania with retro aesthetics but a very modern level of polish, fluidity and user-friendliness. It features a rather unique take on a typical double jump called "cloudstepping" that recovers your jump when you hit an enemy, a projectile or an object before landing, allowing to jump again and again and again if you manage to, thus staying in the air for a long time and feeling like a cool ninja.

Another unusual trick of this game is that it consists of two distinct halves (though it’s not a 50/50 split in terms of runtime, more like 40/60 or even 30/70, but it’s still sort of like Act 1 and Act 2). The first one plays like a strictly linear, “keep moving to the right” platformer, while the second one lets you freely roam the old locations and discover their new secrets (as well as paths to some new locations). Metroidvania elements are still pretty light here, and you’re unlikely to get lost or to discover something wholly unexpected, but it does add a fair sense of exploration. I would agree with a common complaint about mild repetitiveness, though, as fast travel points are scarce and the map is not very interconnected, which leaves you to go through some parts over and over again.

However, where I think The Messenger shines best is at the base platforming / combat. The aforementioned cloudstepping, along with a few more typical mechanics like propelling yourself forward with a grappling hook or bouncing against enemies from above (and along with just generally well-programmed movement basics), creates a very pleasant gameplay loop. It’s just one of those nice indie games where traversing the levels and slashing away at the enemies feels so smooth and satisfying. I think it’s also a great game for speedrunning, if you’re into that sort of thing.

I also really liked the first half of the story, told mostly through optional conversations with the local shopkeeper; it had some witty, self-aware and well-written jokes (the text flows as smooth as the platforming here) and culminated in a seriously cool twist that felt both ridiculously funny and ingeniously planned at the same time. The second half impressed me much less, as it tried to get more serious both with metacommentary (talking about the nature of storytelling but saying nothing particularly interesting or new) and with general worldbuilding (which in the end amounted to a rather typical fantasy backstory awkwardly delivered in a sudden big infodump right before the final level). The shopkeeper also started to feel like an overly blatant author's mouthpiece here. But, honestly, by that time the story had already delivered more than I tend to expect from this kind of games, so I didn't mind such hiccups at all.

The difficulty is pretty accommodating: if you're experienced with the genre, you'll probably breeze past most of it while feeling good about your skills, but even if not, you're unlikely to get overly frustrated either. The length is just right to not overstay its welcome too: you can complete it in about 12-15 hours, and getting all achievements doesn’t even require a full second playthrough, only a small part of it.

All in all, The Messenger is a really easy recommendation, and should work well either as a gateway game for the genre newcomers or as a worthy addition to a long list of favorites for the indie veterans.

If you’re going for all achievements, I recommend looking up “I Swear It’s My First Time” (the only achievement where a guide is pretty much mandatory) once you’re done with “Act 1”; you won’t be spoiled on anything important but will get an extra little challenge that I personally found more fun and less difficult than it looked, and that added a bit of variety to “Act 2”.

Also, please do try to open the cabinet, repeatedly, unless you are being asked to (in that case, please do try to NOT open the cabinet, repeatedly).

It is a crime that The Messenger isn’t talked about as much as it deserves to be.

I never see anyone talking about this game, and that’s a damn shame. The Messenger is so stupidly good, and probably one of my favorite platformers of all time. The Messenger has everything a good 2d platformer, or even game in general, should have. The combat, although simple, is insanely satisfying. Just running and constantly slashing is just so fun. The abilities are all fun and pretty necessary, giving you a reason to want to get them. The story isn’t really that impactful, but it’s memorable and FUN. This is also just one of the *coolest* games, and probably not for the reasons you would think. Unfortunately, talking about it even remotely would spoil it.

The cloudstep mechanic is one of the best combinations of genius and fun. This is probably one of the most unique gameplay mechanics in this game, and it is SO. GOD. DAMN. FUN. Anything that you can hit, including projectiles, will, when you hit them, give you an extra mid-air jump. This is great for platforming, it's very fun to use, and it can save you from death very simply. This is honestly one of the best platforming mechanics in a while, but unfortunately it would really only work in a game like this. Thankfully this game works with it *extremely* well though.

I mentioned the story and humor before, and they are TOP TIER. In my head at least it has that classic Devolver humor, but I think what I think of as Devolver humor came from this game. The humor is on point, it’s meta, and it’s just really good comedy. I can’t really mention the story without spoiling, but it doesn’t take itself too seriously, it’s fun, and it’s funny.

Give this game the praise it deserves.

Objective - 8/10;
Subjective - 8/10;

Despite some occasional silly music, extremely wonky mid-air gliding attack controls and some utterly TERRIBLE fast-travelling mechanics, The Messenger manages to do something that many other retro-styled indie platformers fail at - surprise you. One second it's linear 8bit Ninja Gaiden, the next it's linear 16bit Shinobi, then the next it's Sonic CD time-travelling with non-linear Castlevania levels branching to each other - and that's not all! Mix that in with great bosses, unlockable powerups, plenty of optional collectables and witty writing; and you are left with an extremely unique, rewarding and challenging action platformer that is totally worth it for the real-time 8bit and 16bit switching alone.
